Raw_Narrative: After taking off from the Air Attack base at 1130 for the Dinely Fire on Tulare Unit, Cal Fire, I was programming in the incident frequencies and the AM 3 radio shut off and would not come back on. I took the pilots AM 1 once we were clear of tower traffic with Fresno and used that as 122.925 for briefing victor. I typically use AM 3 for tactical rotor traffic, so I used AM 2 for that function. I would have typically not continued to the incident without all of the radios working, but there was an immediate structure threat reported so we continued to the incident. We were relieved by AA-XXX at 1230 and returned to FAAB. We went U/A upon landing at FAT.

At 14110 after a shutdown the helicopter was going to reposition closer to the fuel truck. After starting and lifting to about 15 feet the engine lost power then caught and lost power again the helicopter wobbled for a second or two then was put on the ground by the pilot. The pilot said he lost power caught then lost it again. The ship was put down from about two feet in height. XXXXX XXXXX HELB said he heard the tail roter slowing from a position about 300 feet away. Ship placed NA at 1415.

Tanker XXX, a SEAT assigned to the Aerial Task Force, was struck by lightning during suppression operations while assigned to the Rattlesnake Fire located 20 NM east of Mesquite, NV. The damage was discovered at the end of the day while the plane was being maintained. The exact time of the incident is unknown and the pilot could not recall the event or even flying near thunderstorms. However, there were isolated storms in the vicinity of the fire and flight path to the reload base in St. George, UT. The strike was apparently isolated to 2 zeus fittings on the front left engine compartment cover. The fittings (about 10'''' apart) were charred black, but no other damage inside/outside the engine compartment was visible.
While performing bucket drops on the Balls Canyon Fire, a military C-130 was observed by ground personnel flying low level through the fire area. A TFR of 10,000 feet by 5 miles was in place.

On Tuesday while working the Snow Fire on the San Bernardino National Forest T-xx came in to the San Bernardino Airtanker Base to get a load of retardant. On his roll T-xx asked me to go outside and look at his gear while he flew over the base and see if the right landing gear was still down. When he flew over we discovered the right landing gear was still down. I told T-xx that his gear was still down. I asked if he would like me to inform Aircraft Rescue, and he advised me that he was going to head to Chico and have his mechanics look at the situation. I advised South Ops, FICC and R-5 RASM of the situation. On the way to Chico T-xx Jettisoned his load at the San Bernardino Jettison Area. At 1850 I called CIC and got word that T-xx landed without incident at CIC at 1842. I contacted R-5 RASM and made sure that he had gotten the news.

Door opening in flight - Pilot and ATGS had boarded the aircraft through the right forward door, ATGS secured the door after boarding. Approximately two minutes after take-off, the door came open. Pilot communicated to the tower that we would be returning to the airport for an open door. The aircraft was landed, and the door secured. The aircraft taxied back to the runway, took off, and completed the mission as planned.

After take-off, acft could not retract left main gear. Flight manual procedures were followed which directed the crew to lower the gear. A safe gear down and locked indication was displayed. Once a safe indication is indicated no further trouble shooting is allowed in flight. Flight engineer visually checked for safe indications thru inspection windows. Retardant was dumped at the fire site due to its proximity. Acft landed at IWA without incident.

While on an Air Attack mission to Fire #846 on the Ochoco NF, I overheard Central Oregon Dispatch telling T-xx the contact on the fire was Recon 1.  T-xx made several attempts to contact Recon 1 on the VHF-AM frequency 132.475.  T-xx then contacted dispatch who then contacted Recon 1 on the FM frequency to call the airtanker on the VHF frequency. I then could hear Recon 1 coordinating the drops between T-xx and the ground.  As the ATGS Coordinator for the Pacific Northwest Region, my records indicate the observer in Recon 1 is a trainee ATGS and has not completed the task book.  From the radio conversation between Recon 1 and T-xx, the coordination was satisfactory with no problems.  My concern is where do we draw the line.  If it is ok for a Recon observer to coordinate one airtanker drop, is it ok to add one helicopter?  Then perhaps a load of smokejumpers?I am not sure what all was envolved in the request to have Recon 1 coordinate the drops. I do know the Captain of T-xx is carded for Initial Attack.

Helicopter was grounded and made unavailable at 0800 PST.

During a flight from FBK to BTT one of the 2 FM radios {Technosonic TDFM-136A}showed an error message. The problem could not be resolved.The flight crew was able to maintain safe operations with one FM radio.  AMD technical services was notified.  BLM HOS 7/17/10

Operation on the Six Rivers National Forest, Young Fire began on 8/18 with the DOI agency FireFly VTOL UAS. The 8/25 afternoon IR reconnaissance flight landing concluded with a propeller strike. The approach was set in guided mode with an automated RTL landing. Within approximately 5 meters from the takeoff location a side gust of wind pushed the UAS off target completing the landing 12 feet from center point where the ground was struck breaking the tips of two of the six propellers. No other damage occurred to the UAS.
The tanker base telephoned an off time to dispatch of 1530 with an ETA to fire of 1555 hrs. Pilot did not check in and flight follow with dispatch center.

We had a normal takeoff and climb out. As we were about to level off we recieved a Master Caution light associated with a Right CSD Oil Pressure Low annunciation. We leveled off, checked the gauge, which was pegged, and then began to get into the QRH when lights, screens, etc. began to flash intermittently. The generator was immediately tripped and the CSD red guarded disconnect switch was accomplished after that. We turned on the APU and finished the checklist in the QRH. We then determined the best course of action was to return to base with the load. An uneventful landing was next with a taxi to our maintenance personnel finishing of the event.

Pilot's narrative 8/27/02:  On 8/25/02 after departing airport for patrol flight, I saw that there was a vapor of fuel coming off the right wing of the Cessna 182.  I was only two miles out from the airport.  After returning to the airport, another company pilot who is also an A & P, adjusted the right wing fuel cap so that it would close tighter.  Then I test flew the aircraft, and determined that the problem had been fixed.

On 5/25 aprrox. 1300 on the Bluff Fire B.D.F. I observed Helicopter 554fly over Helitanker 792. It looked like Helicopter 554 and Helitanker 792were going to collide, Helicopter 554 with the jettisonable bucket over flewHelitanker 792, from my vantage point it looked like the bucket of 554 over flew Helitanker 792 within 20 feet.
On startup to head to a new start a chip light was detected on the main gearbox.

While performing a longline mission, the nine pin plug on the belly of the ship detached. The plug was not originally taped per instruction of the pilot. He informed that it was not necessary for this ship as they had performed this type mission numerous times before with no trouble. The next morning, 8/12/00, during preflight, the pilot found a small ding w/ chipped paint on the belly of the ship toward the rear. It was suspected through investigation, that the damage was caused by the disconnected plug swaying loosely in flight. Later in the day, approx. 1500, the plug detached twice again even though it was taped this time.

This is to doument Tanker 65 being unavailable for dispatch from 1550 to 1740.Panel engine gauges.  The power cable for this was left off the breaker whena new light circuit breaker was replaced in the panel.  A & P mechanic Norberg made the repairs.

During a 50 hour inspection the FBO mechanics noticed one bolt missing and one bolt loose on the rear mount of the front turbo charger. The bolts were replaced with bolts that had holes for safety wired and both were safety wired in place.

We departed Santa Fe Airport westbound. As we were climbing, the rate of climb was about 60% what it should be.  There was a fluttering noise apparent in the cockpit. The pilot turned off the Air Conditioner but the flutter continued.  The gear down indicator lights were not on but the pilot checked the gear up lever and found it was not fully engaged in the upright position.  He pushed the gear lever into its full upright position and the fluttering stopped.  Apparently the nose wheel did not fully retract until the gear lever was fully in an upright position.  The aircraft resumed its normal rate of climb after the nose wheel was fully retracted.  We continued with the mission.  The gear down lights were operating when we returned to the airport.

Upon attempting to land after conducting night aerial ignitions the aircraft collided with a tree, tilted and fell about 15' to the ground. The aircraft incurred broken props, broken arm locking tabs, and a broken landing leg. The Ignis housing was cracked around the 3D printed plastic main body. The pilot stated that he had lost perspective of the aircraft position and the pad. He also said that he could not see the tree line as it blended in with the darkness. There was very little natural illumination and we were using truck headlights to light up the pad.

Original Text:Tested Premo machine at helibase before loading in the helicopter. Everything ran fine. Landed at helispot and shut down. Took doors off helicopter and mounted Premo machine to the helicopter. Had the pilot turn on the battery to test machine for the go/no go checklist. Everything was operational. Turned off the machine, filled out the paperwork, and waited for the call from the DFMO to start aerial ignition. At 1335 the DFMO said he was ready for the helicopter. Flew to the burn, reconned, and made a plan for ignitions. Firing Boss gave me the go ahead to start firing. Turned on the Premo machine and it ran for a short period{2 seconds}. The drive line quit running so I notified the pilot then pulled out the knob and manually turned it figuring there was a jam. I dropped a couple of balls and let the knob pop back in. The machine still wouldn`t run so I checked the switches and pop out circut breakers. There was no lights on but the water pump would still work. Couldn`t find anything wrong with the machine. Decided to set down to look at the machine better. The pilot set down on the dam adjacent to the burn. Took top off the machine and couldn`t find anything wrong. Then I could tell the 5 amp fuse was blown. Had to go back to the helispot where the equipment was for the machine. Landed there and tried 2 fuses and blew both of them. Had the pilot shut down the helicopter to look more thoroughly at the machine. Took the top off the machine, unplugged the power supply wire and plugged it back in and put another fuse in the 5 amp. Had the pilot turn on the battery and instantly the connection on the back side of the switch panel went to smoking. Checked the wires and couldn`t find any bare spots where it could be grounding out. Decided to go back to Helibase to swap machines and work on the broken machine. Hooked drive motor up to inverter and instantly it blew the fuse in the inverter. Found corrosion around the connections on the back side of the switch panel box. Took the 3 prong connection{`IN` wire} loose from the switch panel box. Realized the prongs were burnt and the connector was cracked between 2 prongs.
After finishing Prescribe Burn and while landing at the Helibase and shutting down the Fadec Degrade Light came on.

WADNR UH-1H xxxxx was dispatched to the Ryegrass Coulee fire in the vicinity of Vantage, WA at 0730, 07/10/2018. xxxxx flew one fuel cycle and then landed at the helibase/ fuel site for a fuel and hold. At approximately 11:00 Air Attack requested xxxxx for bucket work, while lifting to leave the helibase a chip detector and warning light activated. The pilot contacted air attack and informed him the aircraft would be down for maintenance. xxxxx set down at the helibase, contacted agency mechanics and went through the proper procedures to isolate and remedy the issue. After the appropriate steps were taken the agency mechanic cleared xxxxx for incident operations. The aircraft finished up the day and returned to ellensburg base with no further issues.

Helicopter was tasked with flying three FBAN personnel on a reconnaissance mission from Ukiah Helibase to the August Complex West Incident to analyze the fires' behavior and gather information needed to plan future suppression efforts and update maps. Aircraft was tasked with this mission immediately after leaving Eel River Helibase, and landing at Ukiah Helibase, where the pilot received a briefing from the Helibase Manager, a map, and an IAP. Multiple frequencies in the Air Ops Summary (ICS 220) were incorrect, so an updated list of the correct TX and RX frequencies for those channels was given to the pilot before departing Ukiah Helibase and the pilot was advised the frequencies were correct on the Incident Radio Communications Plan (ICS 205) were correct. Shortly after departing Ukiah Helibase, West HELCO attempted to cancel the aircraft due to poor visibility, but could not establish communications with them. After failing to reach the helicopter on the radio, West HELCO contacted Ukiah Helibase Box and asked that they try to contact the helicopter and relay that they had been canceled due to poor visibility. Ukiah Helibase Box was unable to establish communications with them either. They were finally reached via cell phone with West HELCO's instruction to return to base, and the information that there was a failure to establish communications via radio was relayed. The helicopter returned to Ukiah Helibase and began to troubleshoot the communications failure.

Our helicopter unit was dispatched to a wildland fire. En route to the fire the hinged doorpost panel on the left side failed to latch after unloading cargo. Upper portion of the panel would not latch due to miss alignment of the door pin. Door was removed from aircraft and the mission continued.

While delivering a sling load consisting of a 132 gallon blivet tank and two boxes of MRE rations,(rations were packed in a 300lb.rated, white nylon colored intuna netin, NFES 0795)to the xxxxxxx Inc. the pilot glanced down at the external load to check its condition in flight and found the load to be flying satisfactorily. Approximately 10 to 15 seconds later he looked at the load again and noticed the two boxes of rations gone. Knowing the approximate airspeed and heading to the helispot, the location of the rations is believed to be approximately T25n, R11E, sec. 29, sw 1/4 which is a remote,unpopulated,unroaded area on National Forest lands. Upon inspecting the net, it appears the corners of the MRE boxes chaffed through several cords and allowed the boxes to fall through the hole. The age of this particular net is unknown but was still in it's orginal packing box and this was it's first use. At this point I will not use anymore of of these nets to fly cargo until it is determined what caused this particular net to fail. I will ship this net to MTDC for their evaluation.

Intermittent issue to bring flaps up for three days prior to this event. No issues to bring them down but after drop flaps would stay indicated at half on way up while lever in up position. Pilot had to wiggle the lever and eventually they would come up. Base Mech. was working on the issue. Cleaning canon plug and changed  transmitter. 

Left brake was changed as well in this period of time.

Later, While coming back to land on an empty tank with gear down and locked, pilot smelled a heat/rubbery smell and saw light smoke appearing from the vents and main cabin.

Landed and shut down the aircraft. Pilot noted left hydraulic gauge indicated 1700psi (Normal Ops is 1500psi)

Pilot ferried Tanker to MCC the next day with gear down and locked.

Flying Fire Managers on Pattengail Fire Recon. Air Attack~above helicopters~air attack complained they could not see me on TCAS, but could see the helicopters below me. Reason is the helicopter''s transponder attenna is housed in plexiglass nose which transmits through. My transponder attenna is on the bottom of my fuselage. Air attack above me could not see me on TCAS as signal won''t go through aluminum fuselage.

Pilot was picking up a load of water with a bambi bucket on the belly hook and as he started out of the dip site he felt a locking up of the the control systems followed by a surge accompanied by a grinding noise in the area of the transmission. This was followed by a complete loss of hydraulic control. An emergency procedure for hydraulic failure was implemented. The pilot was approximately 4 miles from the Bremerton Airport at the time. The pilot jettisoned the water and on short final jettisoned the bucket and accomplished a running landing. The pilot landed the aircraft with no damage to the bucket or the aircraft.An inspection at the airport by the lead mechanic found that an aluminum hydraulic line coming out of the filter had completely broken apart, resulting in a complete loss of hydraulic fluid. The break occurred under  the ferrel fitting and the two ends totally separated.Pilot performed a perfect emergency (by the book) hydraulic failure landing.

Pilot went to refuel at Cascade airport without manager on board and with bucket still attached.  Over flew highway 55 and landed with out a marshler.  Pilot hot refueled with the vendor.The pilot was asked; about fuel situation by the manager at the dip site and replyed that he had 4-5 turns left.  He was informed to hold up on the refueling until the manager checked with the IC to see if they would be released.  While talking to the IC about release, the pilot monitored the conversation.  The pilot informed the IC that he was going for fuel and would return and was told by the IC, inThanks but you are being released.in  The manager tried to contact the A/C on air to ground with no response.  When he returned from refueling, the manager directed the pilot to land and shut down.  The Manager discussed the ship flying off for refueling without a manager on board, flying accross highway 55 with an external load and was asked if he had hot refueled, as it was realized that it was a very short turn around.  Pilot stated that it was a hot refuel and that it was in their ops plan.  Further research revealed that hot refueling was only for EMS operations and stated that the doors on the fuel side will remain closed.  The door was removed and was in the back seat.  The manager explained the need for the manager to be on board when the A/C left the fire when there was no helitack  on the other end, procedures for overflying roads and populated areas with external loads and what the hot refueling procedures were.  There was no flight following from the time that the aircraft left the fire until he was 3 miles out on the return flight from refueling. /s/ Helicopter Manager

We were to relieve Air Attack over the fire. On take off at Tucson the left turbo temp light came on. The pilot adjusted the mixture and it went out but then the right one came on and bounced between 1400 and 1900 degrees. The head temps were good and oil temps were within acceptable levels. We returned to the airport and notified all concerned.

Minutes after launching on an initial retardant run for the congested  Fire, the pilot experienced radio communication promblems. Unable to resolve this issue in flight, the pilot, per policy, returned to base, jettisoned the load, and landed. The radio cord from panel to helmet was replaced, and the SEAT rejoined the rotation.

Upon touchdown at Helibase, the aircraft bounced on wheels and skidded approx. 15 feet before coming to a stop. Crew was unloaded along with gear at Helibase. PIC did a walkaround of aircraft looking at wheels, landing struts, etc. inspecting for any damage, none found. Aircraft was later inspected by mechanics at airport and no damage was found. Upon review of load calculation it was found that aircraft was overloaded approx. 450 pounds for conditions at site. The Helibase was an inground location. Pilot directed aircraft into the wind for landing as per normal. Performance planning was not accurate for actual conditions at Helibase. This responsibility lies with the Helicopter manager who accepts responsibility for incident. We did not confirm actual conditions before landing as is normal SOP, I believe we were mission focused as the fire was in close proximity.

At end of shift on 9/12 fuel truck driver refueled helicopter & departed helibase to refill fuel truck in Winnemucca. Helicopter Manager + 5 helitack crewmembers boarded aircraft and flew from Mahogany Helibase to Winnemucca, NV. Upon arrival at Winnemucca Airport, helitack crewmember discovered that fuel cap had not been secured prior to departure & was hanging by chain.

While on a Recon flight of the NF, the radios went haywire. Then there appeared to be the odor of electrical burning. At that time the pilot shut down the entire electrical system. We headed back to the airport and the pilot pumped the gear down. The pilot did not have the phone number for the tower so he called the Coordination Center to get the number. He then called the tower and got permission to land. The Aircraft was landed without incident. After letting the ATGS out the pilot taxied the plane to a maintenance facility on the field. I called the AMI and left messages on her office and cell phone concerning the incident. The Instructor Pilot also call another AMI to apprise him of the situation. The aircraft was taken out of availability at 1100.

During fixed tank operations on the fire the pilot {also an A&P carded mechanic} noticed an abnormal vibration while en route back to the dip-site. The pilot decided to land and shut down the aircraft in a nearby meadow to perform a visual inspection. He notified the manager immediately via cell phone after shutting down that he might have a problem. After performing the visual inspection, he did not notice anything obviously wrong. He started the aircraft and the vibration became noticeably worse, he shut down the aircraft and called me again. At that time the aircraft was placed out of service.
While heading to Chehalis for fuel, pilot noticed that he could not talk on his intercom or radio. Circuit breaker would not reset, aircraft returned to Randle Helibase and shut down.

Load calculation performed by relief pilot did not match the load calc posted by the previous pilot{same altitude and and temperature}. Manager and relief pilot reviewed the charts and concurred that the relief pilot calculations were correct. The relief pilot discussed performance charts with the previous pilot and determined that new load calc. was correct. The regional helicopter program manager also confirmed that the relief pilot was using the proper load calc.

Shortly after taking off from (GJT)Grand Junction, CO the pilot asked the personnel in the back if they had opened a window and the response was the windows were already opened. We then proceded to the next fuel stop. After landing it was immediately noticed that there was grease all over the tail boom, rotors, and body of the ship. We were at Classic helicopters service center in Page, AZ and we were having a 50 hour done so the mechanic said he would check it out. Upon returning from lunch I was notified that one of the excluder seals had gone bad and lost some of its grease. The mechanic had said we could still fly and it would need to be replaced shortly, after contacting the region nine maintenence inspector it was determined the ship was unavailable until the seals were replaced. It was not determined if the pilots question about the windows being opened could have been the seal going or not. After the initial question no abnormalities were experienced.

During operations on the Sand fire this morning as pic of HT-xxx I want to say how well air assets were handled by air attack and especially Bravo x. With minimal radio chatter they set up safety fences and routes for several aircraft in less than prime conditions so that all could maintain operations with very minor delays in any action. I fully understand that this cannot happen all the time but I am seeing a trend by all lead and bravo assets to allow at least the heli- tankers to stay more involved rather than holding someplace else when conditions allow this to happen. I felt this was important to relay and once again very well done.

During a mission to backhaul cargo off of H-xx, the helitack on the helispot observed two military jets low in the canyon traveling west to east through the TFR, and over the spot. The helitack contacted the helibase and reported the intrusion. H-xxx was enroute to the helibase with an external load, so was not in the area at the time of the incident. There is a MTR in the area, so the Helibase Manager contacted the scheduler to report the intrusion. There were no flights scheduled for the route on that day. AOBD was advised.

Ordered an infra Red flight of our slash burns for 5/19/97. Was told by the vendor that their radio was not operating and so their helicopter had not been carded as yet. They arranged to use a Bell BIII to complete the flight using a Westcam infra red camera. When I arrived at the vendor's the camera installation was nearly complete and the pilot was waiting for the weights and balance calculations. The Westcam camera is a nose mount weighing 80 lbs. It was determined that you could operate as long as no one was in the left front seat and a 30 gallon fuel reserve was maintained. Mission went foreword with out incident however I have real concerns about the IR mounting system which is a temporary mount: 1) It obviously makes a significant change in aircraft CG and reduces the amount of useable fuel (this mission was flown by a light-weight pilot and I'm not aware of any lighter pilots, a heavier pilot may not have been able to complete this mission). 2) The ground clearance of the camera is approximately 4 inches. This is ok if your operating from a cement pad as this mission was but would be unworkable on most fires or other field operations. 3) No agency personnel were on this flight but on some IR missions it may be desirable. I think this system needs to be looked at before someone decides to do so.

A Type I IMT was ordered for the Kinishba Fire on the Ft. Apache Indian Reservation. An ATGS on the team arrived at the Show Low Aiport near the fire with instructions to meet up with an ATGS aircraft.  This occurred.  The ATGS was given orders to launch on a mission.  The pilot of the aircraft infromed the ATGS that he had been ordered by his company to not let this particular ATGS fly in the aircraft.  Due to the need for aerial supervision over the incident, a leadplane and leadplane pilot, based at the same airport, was used for the ATGS assignement.  Later that afternoon the company agreed to fly the ATGS in their aircraft.

While on a routine aerial detection flight, Air-1 the Cessna 210 owned / operated by Smith Air out of Hindsville, AR. was circling to the right over a water source on the Ouachita National Forest @ about 1245 hrs. when the engine started to sputter. The aircraft was immediatly leveled out and the pilot XXX XXXXX adjusted a fuel switch and the engine returned to normal. No other problems were encountered the rest of the flight.

While in transition from the Airport to the fire the snorkel for the Isolair fixed tank impacted the right underside of the tank. The snorkel appeared to be ''''wagging'''' much more than witnessed the previous two days flown missions. The crew stated the snorkel had been removed, and the hydraulic lines had been retaped to the hose portion of the snorkel the evening before. The new position the lines occupy caused the snorkel to react aerodynamically differently. The temperature as well was much warmer and they believe the snorkel hose was made much more pliable {less rigid}.

Aircraft was returned to service after repair/replacement of a hydraulic line that ruptured in the baggage compartment.  During an Air Attack mission another failure in the hydraulic system occurred so we returned to the airport.  It was discovered this failure was on a line in the left wheel well.  It was replaced with rigid tubing consistent with what was removed, and returned to service 9/11.  We were dispatched to a fire on 9/11/14 and 1.2 hours into the flight another hydraulic failure occurred: so we returned to the airport. After inspection it was discover the failure was in the same line that had been replaced.

During support operations of the Bottleneck incident helicopter 4SA was conducting longline operations, providing blivets to crews.  On the third turn, pilot placed remote hook next to the second blivet which was daisy chained to a tuna net filled with bladder bags.  The hitcher was sent in by the radio operator, and accidentally placed the rings of the tuna net on the remote hook (no swivel). While returning to Waldo HLB, Master Caution Light for the generator came on. Pilot reset generator caution light twice and light went off. The Master Caution light did not go off however,pilot tried to reset Master Caution light numerous times, but light did not go off.Pilot landed at helibase safely and without incident.Pilot notified Helibase and helicopter manager of problem.Helicopter Manager made notifications to regional aircraft safety inspector.

On 06-07-2003 when I was flight following with H-332, I could hear the ship's radio when they lifted off the ground in Kingman. Then on first check on status at 15 minutes they could not hear me and went to E-241 to have them relay there lat and long. and to have them E-241 relay. On 7/31/2014 while on the Carlton Complex, xxx dislodged a limb that struck an individual during water dropping operations while working in the South Zone of the fire on Division 3I. The HMGB and the Helibase Manager did not learn of the incident until after shift when South Zone Air Ops notified them that the incident had occurred. Tanker was assigned to the Fire on June 15th, 2013. The aircraft arrived at the Airtanker Base for a load of retardant to bring to the fire. After taking the active runway and beginning the takeoff sequence, the PIC noticed that a warning light was illuminated. The aircraft had not lifted off the ground and was traveling at approximately 80 knots. Since the aircraft was at or below the 80 knot threshold {the low speed regime}, the crew aborted the takeoff and safely stopped the plane on the runway. It was quickly determined that a switch for the de-icing had not been activated which was the cause of the warning light. The switch was turned on and the warning light turned off.
On Runup to respond to the fire, {#}1 Jet would not start. Taxied back to base informed base manager of problem. AMI was notified.

On September 22, 2020 Air Attack was operating over the Auld fire 2.5 to 3.0 miles north east of the French Valley Airport. We had been on scene for approximately 20 minutes and dropped one air tanker on the fire. After the first tanker dropped, we canceled the remainder of the aircraft response and remained on scene assisting ground units with access. While operating over the fire we had been communicating on French Valley Unicom (122.8) announcing to all aircraft our location in both reference to the airport, as well as the local ground reference (Lake Skinner Dam), as well as altitude.  There were approximately seven to ten aircraft that had either entered, or exited the pattern during this time. All aircraft except for this Bonanza stayed clear of the working area and created no issues. We observed the Bonanza in question passed over the fire and 500’ underneath us. As he approached us we called him by N-number, which we obtained via ADS-B. Bonanza did not use his N-number when making calls on Unicom, his communication was incoherent at times, he had difficulty entering the pattern and maintaining spacing with other aircraft in the pattern.  His response was that he saw us and that he was not a factor. While conducting PSD operations, experienced 2 hang fires within Premo Mark III machine. Specifics: balls were manufactured in 1999, new Prestone Glycol, and qualified PLD Operators. Events: Experienced 2 seperate hang fires with 2 different operators. Both events required water flushing and had melted material within slipper block. The first incident was a stuck ball caused when the injection needle hit seam and a piece of the plastic melted in place. The second incident was similar to the first other than in a different slipper block and it actually jammed the machine making the mannual clearing impossible. No balls were dropped out of the unit and all fires were extinguished before leaving units. Conclusion: It is unsure why these misfires happened. Options are: 1. Operator Error 2. Material Age 3. Cleanliness of machine

The incident occurred on the Hastings Fire at the Moose helibase outside Fairbanks, AK. The location of the incident was Pad 5 which had been used by the aircraft in previous days. The aircraft had one Bambi bucket, one 150’ synthetic long line and one 100’ steel cable long line with remote hook staged at the pad. The aircraft flew into the helibase from Ft. Wainwright on the morning of June 5, 2011 and landed at its assigned Pad 5. Upon arrival on the fire, the aircraft landed at its pad and was shut down to await an assignment. The helicopter manager  and helitack came over to the aircraft to brief the pilot and orient the helitack crew member on the aircraft configuration. The steel cable long line was where it had been left the day before with the end of the cable/pig tail laying next to the pad marker. While looking at the long line, it was noticed that there were fresh {wet and muddy} tire tracks across the end on the long line, pig tail and a portion of the cable ~8’ from the end. Helicopter T-2 W/ Bucket was ordered for Greyrock Fire on Tues Morning, March 15 by the Incident Commander. Arriving for inspection helicopter was configured with a Fixed Tank. Helicopter support truck did have a bucket available for use. Inspection did begin after noon and the helicopter was available at 1300. In speaking with the Operations SC of the Greyrock fire, there were two options, 1. Fly one fuel cycle with the fixed tank and evaluate the need to remove the fixed tank and use bucket, or stick with the fixed tank. 2. Wait aprox 1.5 hrs for the tank to be removed and myself be in place at remote helispot to hook the bucket up to helicopter. The Pilot had some ``reservations`` about using the bucket as he hadn`t performed longline work since his carding in May of 2010. My personal feelings at the time were to support option 1. This, to me served two purposes, 1. give the pilot a good evaluation of the fire area and remote helispot, allowing some time for familliarity before immediately performing some bucket work, and 2. give the fire the support of water drops while I repositioned to hook the bucket. The fire choose to go with this option and the helicopter was launched to perform fixed tank drops and evaluate effectiveness and de-tank the aircraft for fuel cycle {{#}}2 if needed. During water dropping mission pilot made 4 drops of mixed effectiveness. The helicopter was requested to be on standby for a new start and was then sent to FNL for refueling and information on the new fire. At aprox 1430, the helicopter was stood down for new fire and requested to return to the Greyrock fire for Bucket work. I relayed this information to the piot and requested that they de-tank the aircraft and fly to my location and I would hook the bucket up. I recieved a radio message @ aprox 1500 from our local dispatch that I needed to call them. They relayed from the pilot that he did not feel comfortable performing bucket work and would not be able to perform the requested mission. I then phoned the pilot and had a good conversation, we talked about the decision to recognize that he was not feeling comfortable about the mission and that the ``perishable``skill of long-lining was a little bit rusty. Rather than proceeding and risking himself and others it was better not perform the long-line bucket operation. The helicopter remained at the airport available for inital attack for the rest of the day. The company mobilized a relief piot to be on shift the next day and this did occur.

Pilot: Incident 206 west of Juntura, OR. Approximately 1620 PST. Just as I was setting up to drop my last bucket on the fire before returning to Burns for fuel I experienced a complete hydraulic failure. I immediately dumped the water that was in my bucket and isolated the hydraulics. I notified Air Attack that I had had a hydraulic failure and that I was going to find a place to land. Air Attack acknowledged my transmission and said that he was going to drop down to a lower altitude and follow me to my landing spot. I turned into the wind and started flying towards the valley that had farm fields. When my bucket was close to the ground, I released it from the belly. After releasing the bucket, I continued my approach to the field and landed without incident.I then gave Air Attack my lat and long and told him to contact my manager, and my fuel/service truck to give them an update. Air Attack told me that he would relay all information to dispatch. While waiting for my manager and service truck to show up the Burns Aviation Manager, showed up to check on me. I informed him that I was okay and enlisted his help to retrieve my bucket. My manager and fuel/service truck showed up about an hour after I had landed. Maintenance was notified and parts should be here in the morning. Manager: All Federal and State contacts were made to the appropriate parties including the Contractor`s home base. Ship was about to go fuel so had been flying for 1.8 hrs before incident. Due to the quick response of the pilot no injuries or damage resulted from this incident. The contractor should be commended for including in their preseason training actual hydraulic failure training in a controlled environment. The pilot responding quickly and decisively to the failure.

AT 1800 we were dispatched from the Tanker Base to a fire on state protection. The other helicopter on the base NXXX launched before us and as manager asked the pilot to follow them to the fire. After clearing the airport traffic I tried contacting dispatch. I could not establish radio communications with dispatch on the Forest direct frequency that is usually used for aircraft in the valley. I had just arrived as Helicopter Manager and had taken over the Manager position from another HMGB. He had informed me all frequencies were in the aircraft and it was ready to go. I did not check before lifting off, as the Helicopter had flew the day before. What I did not find out till later was that they were transmitting OK, but were not receiving well. I tried a few other frequencies then dispatch did hear me on the state repeater, by then we had established VHF-AM radio communication with Air Tactical and the 4 other Helicopters on the fire. Traffic was getting congested so we landed at the Fire Helibase and found a receive tone programmed into the Direct Frequency we were trying to use in the radio. Another potential problem was that I may have also been using the intercom button rather than the transmit button on the radio controls that may have further hampered communications. When landing on the Helibase the Helibase Manager said I was coming through the Air to Ground frequency while instructing the helitack crew to get the bucket ready on the belly rather than a long line. I called dispatch to let them know we were on the ground with 5 souls and everything was OK. They had been tracking us on AFF, so did not worry about the lack of communications. Dispatch did not have a victor radio to hear that traffic. After talking to dispatch and Air Tactical they all felt that we had enough communications to not cause a safety hazard and the pilot and manager are now more familiar with the radio controls. For the Manager both previous CWN assignments were with restricted aircraft and not passenger hauling, so the manager had not used the TDFM for 6 years. Also dispatch did not have National Flight following capabilities out of the valley which was another one of the frequencies that the manager had tried to use to reestablish communications.

On July 8th, 2006 at aprox 1450 hrs, Central Nevada Dispatch called and informed us that T-xxx, a severity SEAT based at the Severity SEAT Base, was inbound for a load/return to the fire. Dispatch informed us that this SEAT was loaded with foam and had been unable to locate the fire and now was low on fuel and needed to jettison the load and land at BAM to refuel and reload with retardant. This aircraft (and regular Pilot) had initially been into BAM AAB and received an aircraft and vehicle use inspection and pilot briefing per Interagency policy. Prior to this aircraft’s arrival at BAM on 7/8, He was observed on AFF flying to a couple of locations quite a ways from each other. The Base Mgr. called Dispatch back to determine the true nature of T-xxx’s mission. It was then learned that T-xxx had in fact been dispatched to a fire and had been the unfortunate victim of a WILDCAD mix-up and was vainly searching an area, far from the true location of the fire, long enough he was now low on fuel. The Base then unsuccessfully attempted to contact T-xxx on the National Air Tanker Base Freq of 123.975 in order to relay the Jettison Area lat/long. A quick check of AFF found him just ESE of the airport, the base staff continued to attempt to contact him and was just about to call him on the District FM freq when he was observed jettisoning his load at the mouth of Hilltop Canyon. As this is a seasonal waterway and not the approved jettison area the Base Mgr. called the Severity Seat Base and spoke with the SEMG who said the pilot was a level II relief pilot, not the regular pilot, and had in fact been briefed, as per policy, but had never been in to BAM. (Also learned in later conversation with the pilot was the fact that he had only performed aprox 20 actual fire drops in his career and was a little apprehensive about his performance. This would factor in to the reason the Base Mgr. chose to discuss the intended mission with the Smokejumper spotter.) Interagency policy states that the first time during the season a tanker pilot arrives at a Large Tanker Base he will shut down his aircraft and receive a briefing from the base staff. This was the main reason this aircraft was shut down and the pilot given a briefing. Several other factors were starting to point to the need to ensure this pilot got a thorough Base briefing. A quick list of those factors were: No contact on the National Tanker Base frequency 123.975, either when inbound or on the ground; No knowledge of our jettison procedures or location; (ie; not dropping over waterways, lakes, etc…) No knowledge of BAM Ramp Procedures; Confusion surrounding the actual location of the fire. During the time that T-xxx was getting fueled the Base Mgr. was in contact with Dispatch to determine the correct lat/long, later confirmed with the pilot. While in contact with Dispatch, he also learned that a load of jumpers had been unable to jump the same fire due to erratic winds over the jump site, and that the jumpship was also inbound for fuel and would then be headed back to the Bone Fire to staff it. The Base Mgr. decided that this was a good opportunity to touch base with the jumpship spotter, who had ordered the SEAT, and really nail down the plan for the retardant mission for the new pilot, as well as discuss the winds encountered over the fire. This was accomplished and T-xxx was returned to the retardant rotation.

Retardant crew was loading a P2V airtanker in pit 2 when a SEAT came into pit 1 for hot load. The crew began loading the SEAT using the SEAT loading pump. This left one MXMS at the meter stand watching two meter displays while the other MXMS ran the engine driven SEAT pump. In the middle of both loading operations the retardant density on the SEAT meter suddenly increased and loading became sluggish. At nearly the same time the loader on the P2V announced that loading was sluggish as it appeared that the pump kept quitting. The MXMS at the meter tried to discover why there seemed to be an obstruction to the water flow and tried working valves etc. There seemed to be some confusion about why both loading operations were experiencing problems so the base manager radioed to the MXMS to discontinue loading the P2V and concentrate on what was wrong with the SEAT operation. All attempts to regain water by valve switching proved ineffective and the SEAT load was discontinued at 6875 lbs by the meter although visually short of a load. The SEAT then returned to the fire. Loading the P2V was restarted and without the noise of the running SEAT it was obvious now that the main pump was indeed running but experiencing the same sluggishness with an apparent loss of water. The tank light system immediately indicated with a red light that 2082 was reached and the loader stopped the pump. An aircrew member told the loader to “ignore the lights” and continue loading. The pump was restarted but still producing little flow and elevated density at the meter. So loading was discontinued at 18,065 lbs at the meter while the aircrew indicated full load had not been reached. The P2V returned to the fire. After both aircraft had left the base it was discovered that the water supply valve had not been open and the water tank had run dry. The valve was opened and the water tank began to recover. When the SEAT returned to reload, the SEAT loading pump would not recover a prime against the check valves and a decision was made in conference with the pilot to load using the main pump as it would have enough “pull” to recover a flow. This worked and the SEAT load was finished in specification and without problem using the main loading pump. When the P2V returned the reload went without incident.

A low pass was made over the jump spot, and hazards were identified prior to jumping.  The spot was about 3/4 of an acre across a very moderate slope with alternate spots available, and upslopes winds at ground level.  Wind drift was determined to be approximately 250 yards. On July 24, 2017 the flight crew of a Helicopter on an exclusive use USFS contract was working the Preacher fire near Minden, NV and heard radio chatter between Lead {Bravo} and Air Attack about the status of a crew lookout. After significant and sudden growth of the fire there was confusion about the lookouts location. Eventually aerial supervision got a hold of the lookout but they were still uncertain of his exact location. Two helicopters, a CH-47D and a K-Max were just off the drop heading back toward the dip site as Bravo requested one of the helicopters to help locate the firefighter {lookout} in trouble. The CH-47 having 3 crew members decided to take the mission and headed towards the south flank of the fire. The flight crew had just previously watched the fire make a one mile run in under 10 minutes and the fire behavior of the south flank was just as extreme and moving rapidly. Eventually the pilot got into contact with the lookout who said he lit two spot fires to help find him. He didn`t have a signal mirror because he ran from the fire and had to drop all his gear including his fire shelter. The third crew member looking out the back of the aircraft spotted the two small spot fires which grew rapidly in the high winds. Bravo above, watching the fire moving rapidly towards the firefighter {lookout} {it was about 400m from his location} asked the helicopter pilot and the firefighter {lookout} if they were both comfortable utilizing the 2000 gallon bucket as a rescue option and everybody agreed giving the current life threatening situation. The flight crew found two potential landing zones but the spot fires grew too rapidly turning them into unsafe options. Trying to exhaust all options before loading the firefighter {lookout} into the water bucket the crew then considered a two-track road in the immediate vicinity of the firefighter {lookout} and landed safely to load up the firefighter {lookout} internally. We then transported the individual back to the Minden airport where we met an ambulance. An After Action Review took place with the helicopter manager.

While doing bucket work on a small fire, the pilot felt an abnormal jerk after releasing the bucket of water on a target. He made a call to the manager on the fire and said that he had felt something strange when he released the water but that the bucket was still in place. The decision was to land the helicopter and inspect the bucket. Upon inspection it was confirmed that the primary release wire on the Bambi Bucket (model 1214 / 144 gallon) had sheered. The bucket was replaced with the secondary Bambi bucket carried on the fuel truck and the mission continued. Later upon further inspection of the bucket it was determined that the cable had gotten pinched between the pulley and the bracket holding the pulley. This did not allow for the control head to retract the cable, thus exerting intense force on the cable and the cable broke. The bucket was relatively new with only a couple seasons of use. No one was injured, and the last load of water carried by the bucket released from the bucket prior to the cable breaking (thus there was not an unexpected release of water from the bucket).

During PLDO operations, a feed chute blockage occurred, followed shortly by fire coming from the bottom of the exit chute. There is no clear causal connection between the two events. A PLDO trainee was operating the Premo machine, with a qualified PLDO on board to observe. The PLDO-T noticed that the second feeder chute was blocked, but the other three chutes were still feeding. After a brief discussion, it was decided to land at a nearby large meadow to investigate and resolve the blocked chute. En route to the LZ, and approximately 2-3 minutes after the block was observed, all personnel on board smelled something burning from somewhere in the machine, and the pilot could see flame coming from the bottom of the exit chute. The PLDO-T immediately applied emergency water, and the flame changed to smoke. The decision was made to continue with the plan to land at the meadow, but to shift over and land in a patch of snow. After landing, The PLDO-T removed the hopper and saw that there was no ball in the slipper block of the blocked feeder chute. The hopper was replaced and the decision was made to return to helibase to look more closely at what may have caused the fire. At helibase, the feeder chute blockage was identified as being caused by a broken sphere. Half of a sphere was pressed onto a full sphere, making it too large to pass from the chute. The needle of the blocked chute was fairly clean, while the other three needles had buildup. The needles and exit chute were flushed with water and scrubbed to remove buildup before returning to operation. The reservoir for emergency water was checked but did not need to be topped off because little water was needed to extinguish the fire. Another 2000 balls were dropped without incident. On this PLDO operation, a total of 11,000 spheres were dropped. An unusually large amount of ethylene glycol spray was found on the skids and back to the horizontal stabilizer. A previous prescribed fire on the unit had similar results, and with the needles being wet at the area of injection. The spheres used for both projects were from the same cache shipment. The box showed the spheres to be from xxx and showed expired on the cache tags. These observations were logged in order to monitor a possible correlation.

While operating the PSD machine on four fast, the operator noticed a ball jam. The ball appeared to be stuck at the bottom of chute 1. The operator, attempted to clear the jam by turning the manual assist wheel. However, the wheel spun freely. After, trying the manual assist wheel, the operator took another look at the sphere placement and noticed that it appeared to be stuck in the chute above the slipper block. During this chain of events, approximately 30 seconds had passed without the ball catching on fire or smoking. The operator then notified the ignitions specialist and pilot that there was a jam in the machine and only three chutes were functional. The operator also stated that the jammed sphere was not igniting. A few more passes were completed, and then the helicopter set down at the helispot to refuel and clear the jam. While on the ground, the hopper and chute were removed from the helicopter to examine and clear the jam. Upon closer inspection, it was noticed that the sphere had half of another sphere stuck to it. The extra half a sphere prevented the sphere from falling down the chute into the slipper block, thereby creating the jam. The jammed sphere was shaken loose from the chute and the machine was reassembled and ready for continued operations.

This narrative is submitted by XX XXXX AREP for State FS assigned to the XXXX Fire in XX State. The description of the incident below was submitted to the AREP by XX XX of State Forest Service.  The incident involved 2 CL 415`s and the ATGS.  Multiple water drops were carried out that impacted State Forest Personnel on the fire.  Multiple attempts were made to stop the unsafe actions.  Narrative On 11-23-16 around 1545, the Super Scoopers began to fly low to the state fire lines and dropped a load close to the burnout operation to the north {orange circle}.  I reported this to the XX State DIVS and requested that State-XX be informed of this.  The personnel on the line were notified by radio to be heads up on other possible drops.  Around 1625, I tied in with a XX State Dozer Boss {XX} and the State-XX DIVS {designated by the State-XX Team} that we were to begin out burnout operation on the highest point possible near to where they had constructed a dozer line heading down a ridge and tying into a stream {located on the western edge of XX FS operations, denoted by an orange circle}.  At this time the main fire was within 75 yards of the state fire lines near this location.  The State Task Force began a burnout operation by tying into a dozer-constructed safety zone {for four dozers} and carrying fire to the north, away from State-XX resources.  At this time I asked DIVS Echo to inform Air Attack to not drop near the burnout operations.  I received an affirmative over the radio from DIVS Echo.  At approximately 1650, the Super Scoopers dropped two loads on the northern part of the burnout operation, impacting the two Type 6 Engines and the BRIDGE Crew.  I reported this to State DIVS Champion immediately.  Shortly thereafter, the Super Scoopers dropped very close to the State Task Force to the south, and perpendicular to the fire line.  I reported this to the State DIVS Champion immediately.  Then, the Super Scoopers dropped directly on an Oklahoma Type 6 Engine and its crew.  The crew leader informed me over the radio “They are bombing us.  Please ask them to stop”.  I reported this to State DIVS Champion and informed him that this was a No-Go situation and that I was prepared to ask XX State resources to pull off of our lines.  DIVS Champion asked that I try to contact Air Attack on my radio.  I attempted to do so on a channel that the planes and Air Attack were using.  I attempted to inform Plane XXX that drops were hitting personnel on the line.  No response was given.  I attempted to contact Air Attack that drops were hitting personnel on the line.  No response was given.  Shortly thereafter, communications between Air Attack and the plane pilots continued on that channel.  No other drops occurred near XX State personnel and around 1725, the Super Scoopers were overheard to be released from the fire.  At approximately 0100 on 11-24-16, I informed XX XX about this situation and he said that these issues would be brought to the YY State-Utah Team.  At approximately 1330 on 11-24-16 I overheard radio traffic between YY-Utah Air Attack and their ground resources on the eastern part of the fire.  Air Attack was ensuring that personnel were not close to planned drops by a helicopter.  The ground resources responded that they were clear of any drops.  Air Attack responded “Just wanted to make sure we don’t have any more Super Scooper incidents”, followed by on-air laughter by the Air Attack pilot.

On 11 June, 2005, Helicopoter was dispatched to a smoke report on the eastern side of the Forest. Upon departure to the fire, flight following was established through Forest Dispatch via radio and AFF. On arrival at the fire I attempted to contact dispatch through the local repeater. Communication was difficult throughout the fire and attempts were made several times on the other local repeaters. In this area two repeaters were in line of sight from the fire and we could tell we were keying the repeaters. While the lookout, ground forces and chase trucks could hear the helicopter clearly, dispatch could not. The pilot and I checked our radio''s twice to make sure we had the proper tones and frequencies programmed and found no fault with the Helicopter. On the ground the IC also had difficulty establishing clear radio contact with dispatch. Finally I called dispatch on my cell phone from the inside of the helicopter and gave them a size up and other information on the fire. This has been a continuing problem with dispatch this season. Our pilot has also voiced his concerns with the communications system. It can sometimes take a few calls to dispatch before getting a response. In the event of an emergency, such as a mayday call, dispatch may not hear or respond in a timely manner.

During PSD operations, a couple of issues arose will on an Rx Burn on the Angelina N.F. The first issue was during a 2 hour fuel cycle of firing operations. The PLDO had to be prompted by both the pilot and the Ignitions specialist to verify that he had complied with the orders of the ignitions specialist, such as, “ready to start: start firing # chutes and speed: and to stop firing. The PLDO had to be prompted to reply back the orders given so the ignition specialist knew when the machine was firing and when it was cleared. Also sometime during this same flight the PLDO vomited into the hopper of the psd machine and did not tell anyone. The pilot had viewed thru his cargo mirror that something else was coming out of the chute of the psd machine, but didn’t know what it was. He asked the PLDO, ''What is going on with the (psd) machine?'' The PLDO didn’t respond. The pilot repeated the question, the PLDO this time didn’t respond with a realistic answer. When asked again, the PLDO then said he was “putting some water thru the machine”. The machine appeared to be working properly as the pilot could still see the spheres dropping and he decided they could finish ignitions. The PLDO didn’t inform anyone of the situation until they had landed back at the helispot. The pilot later informed me (HELM), that for a second that he thought it might have been smoke or something coming out of the chute, but with nothing being reported by the PLDO of a malfunction or jam he continued with operations. My concern is that no matter what the situation is or how embarrassing it may be, the pilot and aircrew need to be informed. The pilot has many responsibilities and needs to be paying attention to flying the helicopter. If the pilots'' attention is directed at something else rather than flying the aircraft, something is wrong. Here the pilot is trying to decipher confusing information that should have been clear and concise, which took away from the pilot’s concentration of flying that aircraft in a flight profile that is low and slow, even if it only was for a few moments. Finally, if the PLDO is getting sick than they are not functioning at 100%. If their attention isn’t on the psd machine and the firing operations. There is a chance that something could go wrong and not know it because they are concentrating more on not getting sick than doing their job.

I asked the tower to send a ground man to push on my left wing (because no right brake) and I was able to taxi the short distance to the FBO. Just a quick note: once you release the tail wheel lock pin the only way you can steer is with brakes. I then called the tanker base on ramp frequency and gave my stop time. I was able to get the (on call) mechanic to look at the brake, and he determined that the brake was leaking only under pressure. I then called the Billings tanker base by phone and went out of service.

I hope that this Safecom gets wide distribution to all aircraft ground support personnel (fixed wing and rotor). There are some very valuable lessons learned within this Safecom.I was on standby in Grand Junction acting as ATP (Air Tactical Pilot.) It was the end of the standby shift and we had just finished plugging the aircraft with intake plugs, pitot covers and prop stops. I was inside the cabin when ramp manager approached with a dispatch to a fire. The mechanic that is always with the aircraft, standing outside, said that he would unplug the aircraft while I stayed inside the plane. I watched him as he traveled around the airplane grabbing the plugs and other equipment. I watched as he placed the bag of items unplugged into the plane. The cockpit checklist was complete up to engine start and started the right engine. The ATS (Air Tactical Supervisor) yelled stop engine, which I did. At the same time I noticed the ramp manager giving the stop engine sign. There was still and engine plug in the intake of the engine. There was no damage caused, as there were only one or two revolutions of the prop before the cut sign was given (no engine light off). A complete walk around was performed and a restart was done after another complete checklist was completed. Engine was started with no mishap.As embarrassing as this is for me, there are several lessons learned here that I would like to comment on.1.	As pilot in command I should have been the person to remove all the plugs from the aircraft. The PIC is responsible for the pre-flight of the aircraft. It would have only taken me but a few seconds to perform the task and ensure of a proper preflight. This is a classic example of “complacency.”2.	The use of ramp managers and other personnel such as them are invaluable to the safety of the aircraft and the crews in and around them.3.	This situation shouts CRM. In the many years of aerial fire fighting, I have had several ground personnel come up to me and point out things on the aircraft that they had a question about. 90% of the time it was something if importance. The ATS was watching the ramp manager as I was looking at the flight panel. Using the two-crew members in the ASM role caught the engine stop signal way before I would have if it had been a single pilot operation.Job well done on the part of Ramp Manager, because of his actions, we didn’t cause any damage to the aircraft and were able to continue with the mission.

After returning from the XXXXXXX Fire, the pilot fueled the aircraft and then proceeded to taxi across the runway to the Tanker Base. During the taxi, the right engine stalled. A restart was attempted and failed. Subsequent inspection revealed that 2-3 wires were burned and arced inside the engine compartment apparently from exposure to extreme heat from the turbocharger. On 7/28/2004 The wires were replaced and re-routed away from the turbocharger to prevent additional occurences. A test flight was attempted but the right engine mag test failed. Subsequent tests revealed that some spark plugs were fouled/replaced and the test flight was accomplished. Upon return from the flight the pilot opened the cowls for an inspection and discovered hot air coming from the side of the turbocharger waste gate (possibly the original cause of the burned wires). The FS Mechanic Inspector was notified and recommended a closer look at the exhaust components. It was found that the crack in the right engine turbo waste gate was adjcent to an old weld repair. Further inspection from the FS Mechanic revealed no heat shields installed and several repairs were evident on the existing exhaust parts.

This incident occurred during operations on a prescribed burn on the Ava district of the Mark Twain National Forest. The Mark Twain Helitack Crew and Helicopter were supporting the prescribed fire with firing operations using the Premo Mark III PSD machine. During the second set of helicopter firing operations that day, while spheres were being added to the machine from one of the refill bags, the PSD operator noticed a half sphere come out into the hopper. This can be a hazard as there have been a number of previous safecoms written where broken sphere halves have stuck to another full sphere resulting in a chute or slipper block jam {which could ultimately cause a fire in the machine}. After noticing the ball, the PSD operator removed the half broken sphere from the hopper and informed the Pilot and Firing Boss in the front of aircraft what had been observed. Together it was decided that the firing operation could continue, but that the PSD operator would take extra caution to watch for any other broken sphere halves to ensure that they could not jam the machine. This was accomplished by loading the spheres more slowly into the hopper, as to observe every sphere coming out and ensuring the proper condition of each. By the end of the mission after all the spheres had been emptied from the refill bags, no other halves were found and the mission was completed without incident.

On August 6th Helicopter -XXX, an exclusive use type 1 helicopter {Kaman K-1200,} was dispatched to the a fire on the Eldorado National Forest for Initial Attack. At the time of dispatch H-XXX was positioned at another helibase located off HWY 16 approximately 20 miles west of Woodland, CA. The IA Fire was approximately 70 miles east near Placerville Airport {KPVF}. The contractor was equipped with a 660 gallon Bambi Bucket which is capable of being stowed on onboard while in flight. However, due to the buckets weight the pilot is incapable of unloading or loading the bucket without assistance. This creates a challenge when responding to initial attack fires when unloading assistance is not available near the fires location. Before departing the current helibase the HMGB contacted a member of a Helitack crew {HECM} who was also responding to the IA Fire and was enroute to Placerville Airport to see if they would be able to provide assistance with unloading the bucket. It was determined that the HECM would not arrive at the airport in time to assist. A call was also made to the airport itself, however KPVF had down staffed for the day. After further discussion between the HMGB and the pilot, and finding no other options that would result in H-XXX being able to take action on the fire before the end of the operational shift, the decision was made to fly with the bucket and longline deployed on the helicopter. The flight path was adjusted from a direct route to one that would take H-XXX further north of Sacramento to avoid more potential air traffic and ground structures. Ground traffic avoidance was also discussed. H-XXX then departed and responded to the IA Fire where it performed bucket work before returning to Placerville Airport at the end of the operational shift.

I have the radio interference report form and will fill that out as well and forward on through our Forest radio techs.Please pass on to SWCC Coordinator as I have discussed these problems with him.AIR GUARD INTERFERENCE ALONG THE MEXICO BOARDER. Air Guard is receiving interference from a source in Mexico.  When this interference occurs, it is overwhelming the frequency and causes the ATGS to turn down the Guard as far as it will go.  I have noticed it periodically while working in and around Silver City, N.M. and along the Az./Mexico border of the Coronado. I thought I could program both the transmit and receive on the ATGS aircraft to minimize the impact of this interference, but found that is not possible.  I’m not sure if a software or a hardware fix is needed to allow a tone on the receive side. This interference is not constant, but is enough that you are adjusting the volume on a continual basis.FAA ASSIGNMENT OF VHF AM FREQUENCIES FOR EXTENDED ATTACK.On the merritt fire I requested and was assigned extended attack VHF frequencies for Air Tanker and helicopter use.  The frequencies assigned have been common air-to-air frequencies.  I have had interference from Tucson and Phoenix area airports, medivac flights and other private pilots using these frequencies for air-to-air use.  I asked the pilots that I happened to be flying with at the time and they said that these frequencies are common air to air frequencies for anyone to use and we have no right to tell someone to get off, it’s what the frequency is for.This is not satisfactory for our intended use.  We have to have a frequency that is ours alone.  Even if the ATGS is the only one being impacted by this interference the chance that important transmissions being blocked or walked on are too great to continue to use common air-to-air frequencies. This has the same impact as the Guard interference in that it affects the safety of air operations. The three frequencies that were assigned to me for the Merritt fire are; 123.050, 123.025, and 122.750.  All had varying degrees of interference from common air-to-air use.

On 14 July, 2000, Helicopter Nxxxx, a Bell 407 Helicopter, departed Boise Airport (BOI), Boise, Idaho enroute back to station at Garden Valley, Idaho, a trip of approximately 40 miles / 15 minutes.  A precautionary landing was initiated when the aircraft cabin and the fire crew in the rear of the aircraft were exposed to a strong burning odor and fumes from an overheated fan blower motor.The aircraft was held on the pad at BOI for an extended period to allow for air tanker traffic on several large fires nearby.  The pilot turned on the fan blower to provide air circulation for the rear flight crew.  Prior to departure, the pilot shut off the ICS system to the rear of the aircraft.  BOI Tower and Approach were both very busy with the Air Tanker Traffic and the pilot wanted to keep a 'sterile cockpit' in his departure from the airport.  Approximately 4 minutes into the flight, the Fan Blower Motor for the Overhead Airduct Vent System overheated and seized, popping a circut breaker.  Heat generated by the fan blower motor generated a strong smell and fumes in the rear of the aircraft.  With the ICS system off, an inability of the rear flight crew to communicate with the pilot caused some excitement.  When the pilot turned on the ICS system, he was informed of the fumes and smoke in the rear of the aircraft.  The pilot initiated a precautionary landing in a hay pasture near an active sprinkler irrigation system.The helicopter manager exited the aircraft and checked the rear cargo compartment for signs of a fire and heat externally and then internally.  He located a spot inside the baggage compartment on the upper bulkhead and the pilot identified the probable source as the fan motor.The aircraft was shut down and the pilot removed an access panel in the tail cargo compartment and verified the source of the heat as the fan motor.The helicopter manager notified dispatch and contacted R-4 RASM and explained the situation.  The flight crew waited for their helitender and chase vehicles while the Helicopter made a maintenance ferry flight to Garden Valley.  The motor was removed, the circut breaker was zip tied off to prevent engaging and an entry was made in the log book.  That evening the aircraft was released as fit for duty.  A replacement motor is on order.The pilots had been having difficulty with the fan blower unit before, but misdiagnosed it as a problem with the climate control system.  A 100 hour inspection and maintenance interval was coming up where the system was going to be thoroughly inspected and checked.

The following statement is one of four statements received regarding this incident:On Wednesday evening at approximately 2010 an order for all airtankers and a leadplane to launch immediately for the Hungary Fire, which was only 5-7 miles from Reno-Stead Airport.  I was the last airtanker to depart the airport due to refueling.  I could tell from the radio traffic that the situation was confused.  I flew to the inactive side of the fire to hold.  I orbited on the east side until I thought I was nearing my turn to drop.  I proceeded to the west side of the fire and approached the area where the other airtankers were working.  After a short time I decided to exit the area once again due to the difficulity in distinquishing aircraft from all the emergency vehicles on the ground with their beacons on and rotating.  At this point the leadplane called for the tanker to the south to come in for a drop.  As I was south and going south I thought it meant it was my turn.  I started following the leadplane only to look up and see another tanker closing rapidly with me.  It was apparent it was his turn not mine.  I immediately broke hard right to avoid a mid-air collision.  This forced me into rising terrain.  I should have dumped my load and proceeded to the airport to help clear the conjection over the fire.  Instead I saved the load and eventually did drop before returning to Stead.  There were numerous factors that lead to an ever increasingly dangerous scenario.  They were increasing darkness, smoke, the close proximity of the fire to the airport, the large number of aircraft on the fire, the insufficient altitude of the air attack aircraft, the lack of an understood tanker sequence, no overall aircraft control, no holding instructions with assigned altitudes, failure of all participants to call off the operation, and a general panic situation exerting undue influence to act.

The heli-tack crew at the heel of the fire {under the power lines} warned me of the approaching aircraft, but I was unable to contact them on any A/A frequency. The EU helicopter assigned to the fire was engaged in bucket operations, and the route between dip and drop crossed over the power lines that the unannounced aircraft was patrolling. Luckily, the fire helicopter had a frequency used by PG&E and made contact with the utility helicopter after the intrusion. I did the same after getting the frequency, then relayed the incident to my ECC. See attached photo of fire, power lines, and dip site.

I advised the Unit FMO (Montrose BLM) that aerial supervision resources for the incident (FS jurisdiction) should be requested in view of ongoing and anticipated tactical use of aviation resources (multiple airtanker missions, one helicopter and expected media interest).  At the time of this discussion, I was unaware of the status of any outstanding resource orders for either a lead plane or air attack.     While assigned to an adjacent unit (GJD), I completed a partial fuel cycle over the incident later that afternoon, but was dispatched to another incident for initial attack.  The status of aerial supervision assigned to this incident is unknown.The Unit FMO was engaged in extended aerial observation missions over the incident using a local vendor and a portable handheld radio.  The intent of this SAFECOM is to again point out a situation which has been documented over the last several years in Western Colorado/Eastern Utah regarding the short term unavailability of adequate resources and equipment to conduct aerial supervision over an incident.In some situations, fire managers are continuing to 'make do' with regard to the ability to provide aerial supervision in a timely manner.  This situation is incompatible with the interagency emphasis on addressing safety.

After being dispatched to a fire, as aircraft was spooling-up, the marshaler noticed a small amount of fuel leaking out of the drain port under the aircraft and onto the concrete pad. Upon receiving the marshaler''s message about the fuel leak, the aircraft was shut down and everyone exited the aircraft. The leak was not evident until the aircraft was started up. Pilot investigated the cause of the leak and found that as pressure was put on the fuel pump hose during start up, the cock valve did not close and this caused some fuel to purge out into the drain port where the leak was noticed. The valve was correctly positioned and this fixed the fuel leak problem. The small amount of fuel lost was mopped up and dried off the aircraft, and the helicopter was restarted while the marshaler observed the fuel port to make sure no more fuel was leaking. No further problems were encountered.
