On the morning of September 18th, 2014 the aircraft dispatcher at LIFC called Kingsley Field Oregon Air National Guard operations to report that the Klamath Falls Air Tactical Group Supervisor {Air Attack} and Single Engine Airtankers {SEAT’s} would be operating from Burns and Lakeview in support of Bone Creek Basin and Blitzen Fires near the Steen’s mountains. Kingsley asked what the flight level for of the aircraft would be. Per the Klamath Falls Air Attack and the Lakeview SEAT Manager, the aircraft would be flying around 7,500 ft. MSL when enroute to the incident and 8,500 coming back to LKV. Kingsley said that would work for them as the floor in the MOA is 11,000. After speaking with Burns later in the morning the LIFC aircraft dispatcher found out the heavy airtankers would be flying also and relayed that to Kingsley Field. The de-confliction report that morning indicated that Juniper / Hart and Goose MOAs would be active with a floor of 11,000 feet and the following footnote **notified of heavy activity throughout day**.  At the Klamath Falls ATB {LMT}, tankers were on and available. Both aircrews were given the de-confliction information with the morning briefing materials. Both airtankers launched to the Bone Creek Basin fire at 11:30. Airtankers had already launched to the fire from RDM at 1030. It is unknown if those aircrews received de-confliction information at that time. The four airtankers proceeded to load and return from LMT. Tankers 161 and 41 did not receive deconfliction information on the MOAs from the airtanker base at this time. At 1545 the LIFC aircraft dispatch received a call from a Lt. Col from Kingsley stating there was almost an incident within the Juniper Hart MOA. He said that they didn’t know we {federal airtankers} were in there and if the tankers were flying VFR they must have been penetrating the clouds. One of the military planes got close to one of the tankers and they were concerned. The aircraft dispatcher gave the Lt Col the Klamath Falls Airtanker Base Manager’s number as well because he wanted to relay the information to them. Both aircraft dispatchers deconflicted the day prior and in the morning of the 18th.  Another phone call was made to Kingsley on the morning of the 18th to notify of the planned Air Attack flights to Burns from Klamath Falls. Kingsley was updated about the additional orders for Airtankers/SEATs that would be operating to/from Klamath Falls. The Burns Interagency Coordination Center was also notified of the military traffic in the MOA. The Klamath Falls base manager received a call from a Lt. Col. at Kingsley on the afternoon of September 18th. He was concerned that F15’s from the Kingsley base were operating in the Hart South MOA and that airtankers supporting the Bone Creek Basin and Blitzen Crossing fires were crossing the MOA at approximately 13,000 ft. He said the airtankers were “in weather” with low visibility and that there had been a instance where aircraft had been in close proximity. The Airtanker Base manager told him that he would speak to the aircrews and let them know that the MOA is active and relay his concerns. He asked the Airtanker Base manager to send him an email letting him know that he had done this. The manager spoke with each air crew that day which consisted of {3} Tankers. Tanker XXX at this time was already heading for RDM. T XX had been operating across the MOA at about 7500’ and TXX and TXXX had been operating at approximately 13,500’. The TXXX crew mentioned that they had been “on top” of weather on their way over. I told them the MOA was active and expressed the Lt. Col.’s concern. I sent an email to the Lt. Col. letting him know that I spoke with the aircrews. By this time, the airtankers were on hold. They did not go back to the fire.  In the afternoon of the 18th, after all airtankers were on hold, both the LIFC dispatch office and the LMT airtanker base received calls from Kingsley Field. They were concerned that the heavy airtankers were flying at 13,500 and in the clouds and he thought that should be an IFR flight and wasn’t sure why they were flying that high. The Assistant Tanker Base Manager was contacted by Kingsley field who reported an airtanker observed at 11,000 feet in the clouds. The Assistant Airtanker Base Manager mentioned to the officer, that de-confliction information was received and relayed to the pilots of the active MOA’s. The Assistant Airtanker Base Manager then spoke with the aircrews. The pilots stated they had already lowered their routes and had to get around the weather. The Tanker was able to lower his flight paths to 7500. A couple pilots mentioned getting T-CAS hits from jets far overhead. There were no further flights to these fires that day or after. The airtanker base has received word from the National Airspace Program Manager that the military had notified the FAA of these events. On Monday, the 29th of September, the National Airspace Program Manager called the Unit Aviation Officer asking for clarification and information about the events of September 8th, as the FAA was asking if there was a mutual agreement to fly at 7500ft.

On August 16, on take-off roll to the One Eye fire, from Grand Junction, Lead 2-3 ordered the FAA tower to abort my take-off. I heard the call to the tower, on the FAA VHF frequency, possibly to get around the insterile cockpitin procedures, and disregarded it. I did not believe there was proper authority from the lead plane, I had proper dispatch from Western Slope Dispatch, Lead 7-2 was low on fuel but waiting for me, and I was already approximately 75 knots into the takeoff roll. I momentarily hesitated to abort to consider my options. Since I was under the control of the FAA at the time, and I determined that I could SAFELY abort the takeoff, I chose to abort. The takeoff was safely aborted, not for any traffic problem or mechanical problem with the aircraft. It happened the Lead 2-3 thought I was being dispatched to a fire she had been on and had left. I was in fact going to a different fire. This raises some serious safety questions. Does the lead plane have the authority to override a dispatch order? Does the lead plane have the authority to override proper orders and instructions from FAA at an FAA controlled airport? Have I relinquished my authority as pilot in command on my aircraft to the lead plane pilot? What happened to the sterile cockpit procedure? Even if I had been going to the fire that lead 2-3 was on, I feel strongly that it would have been much safer for me to continue the takeoff, get proper cancellation orders and return for landing. This precludes the necessity of making snap decisions based on the decisions made by others than the pilot in command at a critical time in the operation of the aircraft. It should be understood that this is not a personal attack on Lead 2-3. This situation may have arisen with other lead plane pilots. I think that it is imperative that this situation be resolved in the interest of flight safety, and clarification of chain of command and authority.

On 10 August 2019 I was PIC on C-208 on a backhaul demobe mission out of DCK {Dahl Creek}, AK. The first load of backhaul was delivered to PAFB uneventfully @ 1727. We landed back at DCK @ 2022. We loaded the second load of backhaul destined for PAGA. Discussion ensued concerning fueling issues for the medium helicopter that was bringing backhaul from the fireline. Over the course of the summer helos have been using fuel stored in a park service fuel tank. Apparently fuel tracking methods are at best, marginal. The helicopter pilot was unable to get the amount of fuel needed to return to Galena. Options discussed were landing Huslia where I could deliver two barrels of fuel or landing Hog River Mine, which is 50 nm closer to DCK. I expressed concern about duty time issues with me attempting to return to Hog River, the decision was made to meet at PAHL {Huslia} with 2 barrels of fuel. As we started the 208 the helicopter was still shut down with doors open. I made three separate radio calls before takeoff: 1. “Dahl Creek traffic C-208 taxiing from the ramp for takeoff, any inbound traffic please advise.” This call is imperative as the runway cannot be seen from the ramp due to foliage/trees and vice versa. 2. “C-208 back taxi for departure to the west runway 26 Dahl Creek” 3. “C-208 rolling now runway 26 Dahl Creek departure to the West” Time noted 2042. I had just completed the takeoff roll and was 20’ +/- in the air when I heard the radio call ``helicopter departing Dahl Creek to the South``. I did not have time to respond to that call before the helicopter rose from the trees ahead and to my right and crossed the runway north to south maybe 500’ in front of me. I made the radio call “Breaking right” and turned right behind the helicopter climbing behind and above him. I flew to Galena, unloaded cargo, loaded fuel barrels and landed in PAHL @ 2224. After fueling operations we returned to Galena landing 2337. The Galena zone FMO was on my aircraft and the UAM was on the helicopter, both were witnesses to the events described. I would best describe this as an Incident with Potential. As is generally the case a chain of events lead up to the incident. We must stay vigilant and aware. Situational awareness is fundamental. “Hurry hurts and patience pays”.

Approaching SBD for a load and return to the XXXXX Fire, TXXX had a bird strike on the underside of the right wing with damage to the outer flap tab hinge fairing. There was no damage to the actual mechanism.

When I was dispatched from Pubelo to Grand Junction to a fire 8 miles from GJT, I called Pubelo Dispatch to advise them of my ETE/ETA. I advised my ETE and told dispatch I would use FAA flight following. The response from dispatch was that I was not allowed to flight follow with the FAA, I was to flight follow with dispatch. Dispatch does not have radar nor trained traffic controllers, nor in this case a knowledge of flight following prescribed in FS policy. The failure of dispatchers to realize that other aircraft are operating within the airspace and the enhanced safety provided by using the FAA's facilities, is amazing. Using the FAA only helps our ability to see other aircraft and provides us with current weather, and of course an opportunity to be vectored around hazards and other air traffic that are not fire related.To create pressure or demand that we not use the FAA option, only impares our ability to accomplish the mission safely.

As ATGS, the Lead Plane and I were using air tankers {SEATs and LATs} to re-enforce retardant lines that we put in the day prior that the fire had burned through or were getting close to burning through. During this operation we had multiple helicopters doing bucket work and recons. There was one recon helicopter, that we had positive contact with, and were cleared in at 9,500 and below with an altimeter of 2992. They were instructed to avoid the retardant drop area and remain in one division area, which they complied. After orbiting for some time, they informed me that they we returning to helibase. I acknowledged and asked them to stay wide of the tanker drop path which they did. The air tankers were being cleared in by the Lead Plane at altimeter 2992 and 10,500 feet. After initial clearance and target identification they were then cleared to maneuver low level to complete their drops. After completing the mission, I returned to the airport and the aircraft was returned to initial attack responsibility. While en-route I received a phone call from air operations that a SEAT had overflown the recon helicopter while he was orbiting near Helispot A. I went to helibase and met with the manager of the recon helicopter and discussed what had happened. The pilot was not available to discuss it because he was flying, but he did call me later and explained that the SEAT overflew them and he was flying at 8600’-8700’ and the seat was not above the 10,000 ceiling that he should have been to provide for the 500’ separation that is required.

On July 6, 202 at approximately 17:08 PM at Buchannan Field, in Concord, California, a firefighting UH-1H came in close proximity with a departing Cessna Caravan from runway 19R. The helicopter was returning to an incident after refueling at the Pacific States Aviation (PSA) ramp. The helicopter pilot announced the intentions of taxiing from the PSA ramp to the adjacent taxiway, "taxiway Alpha." After a pause on taxiway Alpha to look for traffic, a second broadcast was made stating the intentions of departing taxiway Alpha into the wind with a right turn to the west, crossing the departure end of the 19 runways. The helicopter executed a normal takeoff from taxiway Alpha and turned on course as stated. After completing the initial departure (southerly) then turning to the westbound course, inflight, the pilot checked for traffic from the 19 runways. Once observing the Cessna Caravan departing runway 19R, the helicopter pilot immediately lowered collective while turning away from the departing traffic. After completing a full turn and back on course to the westbound heading, the helicopter pilot resumed normal flight operations and departed the Buchannan Field airspace without further incident.

While assigned to an incident the pilot of a type 3 helicopter was directed to conduct bucket drops in a problem area of the fire. After completing the first drop and refilling the bucket, the pilot was directed by the ground contact near the target to perform a spot drop on a second target approximately 100 yards from the original target. There were no ground personnel in the immediate vicinity of the second target, which was a burning log about 20 feet long. The pilot performed a recon, noting a snag adjacent to the target, and began a slow descent. As the drop was made, the pilot saw the bucket brush up against the snag. {The pilot stated that the helicopter was descending slightly and moving forward at a ground speed of 3 knots per hour at the time of the drop} The pilot perceived the impact to be minor enough not to have damaged the bucket. As a precautionary measure, the pilot notified the Helibase that the helicopter would be returning there to have the bucket inspected prior to continuing any operations.

During a routine preflight inspection in the morning 7/26, I noticed a divot in the left propeller. The divot was located on the leading edge, approximately 5 inches from the prop tip and was roughly the length of a penny in width and half a penny in depth. I grounded the aircraft until further notice and reported the discrepancy to my supervisor and the persons responsible for maintenance of the aircraft. I believe the damage was caused from a rock or bolt making contact with the prop during landing or taxi. A factor which likely contributed to the FOD damage was darkness, as I landed 20 minutes after sunset the previous night. Exacerbating the darkness factor are the lights in the Cedar City ATB light fixed wing parking area, which shine from the ground up, directly into the pilot````s eyes during taxi/parking operations. A parking tender was present, which helped. A factor which may have led to the FOD in the first place may have been the path used by vehicles between the main tanker base vehicle parking lot and the light fixed wing ramp. The path short cuts the paved route to the ramp via a loose gravel two track. See attached images for FOD damages and dirt path shortcut.

Two Modular Airborne Fire Fighting System (MAFFS) aircraft at the Hill Air Tanker Base located at Hill Air Force Base received launch orders to the Danskin Fire located at North 44 degrees 04.27 minutes, West 115 Degrees 49.53 minutes. Air Attack 64E/Leadplane 49 advised MAFFS 1 & 3 to hold in pattern as weather conditions over the fire was experiencing a sand/dust storm preventing any drops. Air Attack then released MAFFS 1 & 3 to return to Hill AFB loaded, as wind conditions were gusting due to a passing front.MAFFS 3 on downwind leg of landing pattern to Hill Air Force Base had a fire indicator light on #3 engine illuminate. Pilot declared an inflight emergency. Crew performed emergency checklist procedures and shutdown the engine. Light remained illuminated and both fire bottles were discharged. Engine indications were normal and visual inspection of #3 was normal. On landing the aircraft cleared the runway and stopped on the taxiway. The crew egressed the aircraft and moved away. The left main tire began to smoke. The base fire crew sprayed the brakes and tires. The left main brake seized.The Hill AFB Crash and Rescue emergency vehicles responded to the inflight emergency. Military maintenance worked with the emergency crews to remove tires, unlock brakes, cap brake lines, reinstall tires and move aircraft off of taxiway.

Replaced retardant tank control box by crew chief prior to duty day. Unit was tested and signed off as operational prior to start of day. After retardant was loaded onboard the aircraft, taxi and run-up were completed. Tank system was then turned on and armed for take-off and taxi to active was begun. At that time the distinct sound of a door opening was heard, and visual check confirmed there was retardant on the taxiway. On August 28, 2013 a cargo mission involving multiple loads delivered to multiple helispots was initiated by a handcrew’s request via cell phone to the Air Ops. At the time, the type 2 helibase had four helicopters, a USFS exclusive use AS350-B3 with crew, a National CWN 214 with a CWN crew, a National exclusive use S-61 with manager, and a National CWN UH-1H {restricted} with a manager and manager trainee. Other HECMs on base were assigned to ABRO, ABRO trainee, and cargo. Supply dropped off the cargo midafternoon and loads were built in the designated cargo area using the HOGE-J allowable from the 214’s load calc. At some point it was decided by HEB2 that the loads should be shared between the 214 and the UH-1H. Helitack in cargo divided up the loads between the two ships according to the receiving crew’s point of contact. It was determined that the 214 would deliver three loads, the UH-1H would deliver two loads, and whoever returned first would fly the last load {total of 6 picks}. The manager and pilots of the 214 were fully aware of their mission and already spooling when an individual came to the managers of the UH-1H with two pieces of paper containing a lat/long, contact, and weight for the two loads they would take. They were told each ship would fly two loads and that there was a fifth load going with the first aircraft back. The managers briefed their pilot, discussing a number of concerns, but determined that the mission could be carried out safely and that they would proceed. The first red flag was that the HECM who brought the load info from cargo did not know the weight of the last load, but that would be easily resolved with a radio call prior to the final pick, and because the 214 would be the first one out they would probably be the first back thus taking the load in question, making the concern irrelevant. The second topic of concern related to the fact that the first pick would not only be the heaviest, but its weight was actually 2 pounds above the UH-1H’s allowable for the day. It was determined that taking a load over allowable was mitigated due to the pick-up and delivery locations being much lower in elevation than the load calc was completed for coupled with fuel burn from a maintenance run-up and power check completed prior to the mission. All involved agreed the mission could be safely completed. As the 214 called deck to lift and the UH-1H began his start up, ABRO{t} called cargo asking for manifests and other info relating to the mission. A very confusing radio exchange in which cargo told the ABRO{t} “load 3 will be {{{{#}}}}1 going to ____, load 1 will be {{{{#}}}}2 going to lat/long with a contact of ___, BREAK.” At which point ABRO{t} stepped in saying “all I need to know is what is the first load out, and who is it going to so I can inform Div.___,” and to “please bring the manifests for each load to the box.” After the 4th pick, the UH-1H managers saw that there were actually six loads… not the five they were briefed about. Due to a seemingly large amount of confusion at the helibase for a simple cargo mission, the UH-1H manager decided to walk down to the box and look at the manifests and posted load calcs. He discovered a number of discrepancies in the numbers on the manifests. The allowables for all manifested loads were based off of the 214’s HOGE-J, which was 376 pounds heavier than the UH-1H’s. The manifest showed a remote hook with longline at 60 pounds, when the UH-1H hook and longline combined weight was 91 pounds. Although the cargo area was too far from their pad too see all the equipment clearly, the manager could tell each load consisted of three daisy-chained nets or blivets, which should’ve used two leadlines and three swivels. The manifests did not show the appropriate weights for that combination of equipment

This was an incident when the aircraft was not running and tied down. The Mechanic was climbing down from the top of the Boing Vertol and lost his footing and fell to the ground. He also hit the wheel well on the way down. He was transported to the hosptial via ambulance for possible back and head injurys. There was not a witness to the actual fall but the helicopter manager observed the mechanic walk stiffly and disoriented away and more or less slumped down by the fuel truck and became unresponsive. Helicopter manager and one of the pilots responded to the mechanic and called 911 for help. Several hours later the doctors at the hosptial determined the mechanic did not have a broken back, but did have a mild concussion and was later released. This is a heads UP to be vigilant be aware and remind everyone that things can and do go wrong in the blink of an eye even when the aircraft is sitting on the ground and not running

The first jumper made it into the spot ok.  The second jumper, made an appropriate approach and descent into the spot and brushed a tree.  His chute collapsed and he fell between 30 and 50 feet.Jumper immediately complained of lower back pain.  The rest of the load jumped to help with the injury and evac.  A helispot was selected on the ridge top and improved for the medical helicopter.  The copter arrived at about 2046 MDT and the injuried jumper arrived at the helispot at about 2115 MDT.  The copter landed at Kootenai Medical Center in Coeur d` Alene Idaho at 2155 MDT.Jumper substained a burst fracture of the Lumbar {#}1 vertebra and possible damage to the L-5 vertibra. H-xxx was dipping out of a dipsite that they and another Kmax had been using for the past two days on the East Canyon Fire. Half way through H-xxx second cycle of  bucket work, the pilot was burping water from his bucket to get a positive rate of climb out of the dip. H-xxx then had a wind switch and started to settle and started to burp more water from his bucket but his rate of decent continued. At that point H-xxx released all his water to avoid damage to his bucket and longline. The pilot noticed where he dropped his water that it was possible the water and/or his bucket may have damaged a fence. 
H-xxx immediately notified Air-Attack of what happened and finished his cycle dropping water. After tapping the fence H-xxx moved further back in the dipsite and took a little less water.

At the time this happened the ground crew was talking on the radio about a huge wind switch. At Cortez airport the winds were at 8kts gusting to 26kts reported by CEZ ASOS.

A ground crew was sent out to the dip site and did not find any damage to the fence but did find a screw that was protruding from a fence post that the bucket had scraped on. The bucket did have a light scratch, but no significant damage was done.  Pictures attached.

Dispatched out to an initial attack late in the day dropped off two personnel on the fire. Afterward, the helicopter relocated to the dip site and reconfigured for bucket operations. The manager and pilot decided to leave the cargo basket attached to the aircraft while performing bucket work instead of attempting a single person removal of the basket. During the first bucket drop with an uphill approach, the pilot grazed the top of a Ponderosa pine that was roughly 60 ft. tall with the side of the bucket. When bucket operations commenced ground personnel moved away from the line and were congregated in an open area in view of the pilot. From this location, the hand crew that was assigned to the fire also observed the strike.   During the approach, primary ground contact and pilot believed bucket would pass over the treetop. However, firefighter further downhill saw that contact was possible from their angle of observation but did not interject. When the strike occurred, primary contact saw the strike and made the call out but the pilot had already realized the issue and pulled up and to clear the tree.  The pilot returned to the dip site, contacted the manager and the bucket was inspected for any damage. Bucket strike occurred around 1920 in a narrow drainage with shadows becoming an issue for both ground observer and pilot in regard to depth perception. 

No damage to aircraft, equipment, or human life.

this was an incident with potential. 08-01-2007 bucket work on the lightning fire was performed by xxx. retardent was used. pilot returned from fire and shut-down for mandatory break. when asked how things were going with missions, pilot informed me that something inside of rinse tank ``snagged`` a bucket support cable and broke it. we informed helibase immediately of the problem and the mechanics proceeded to fix the broken cable. cable was fixed quickly and no loss of availability was incurred. day was close to ending, no more missions for the day. we were informed at evening de-briefing that nothing was out of the ordinary with the inside of the tank. 08-02-2007 over morning coffee and before helibase briefing my trainee and myself drove to the retardent site to see and inspect the tank ourselves. we inspected the tank and shot some pictures and this is what we think. when ship nears the end of its fuel cycle, they wash the buckets in a rinse tank. this is what happened as far as i can tell.....the bucket was lowered into the rinse tank, the control head was lowered past the top of the tank and hung down the side of tank. as bucket filled, bucket sank, pilot began to lift. the cables of bucket snagged on the corner of a ``sight window`` on side of tank. helicopter kept lifting and cable was snapped. pilot flew back to middlefork helibase. none of the personnel at the retardent site saw this happen.

At approx. 1430 hours while conducting sling cargo missions to H-1 on the Fire, the winds at the ASOS, 27 NM to the north was reporting winds from the southeast approx. 26G36. The pilot approached the cargo area at H-1 and deposited the load onto the cargo area, after the load was on the ground there was gusty wind conditions that caused the pilot to re-grip the cyclic, while re-gripping the cyclic the pilot inadvertently allowed his small finger on his right hand to contact the electric belly hook release. The line departed the aircraft and fell onto the top of the load. There were no personnel near the load or in danger of being struck by the falling line. The pilot contacted the personnel at H-1 and advised he would land and they could look at the nine-pin attachment at the hook and determine if it looked like there was any damage. It was determined there was no damage, the pig-tail and line were reattached to the belly hook, then the {{#}}1,2,3 tests were completed with the hook operating as required. the pilot then took off and returned to the Helibase to inspect the pig-tail and continue operations. Determination was made that a casual factor in the incident was the absence of a guard over the electric belly release on the cyclic. Some aircraft have it and some don`t.

On the morning of the second day of an aerial ignition operation, it was discovered that the manual release cable was broken and it and the electrical wires had been heavily wrapped with electrical tape. The HECM immediately notified me and the pilot of the problem. The pilot felt that it was no big deal as he still had an electrical release. I immediately removed the aircraft from service and was informed by the pilot that the mechanic had already flown from Salt Lake City, Utah to Minneapolis, Mn and was currently driving to Ely with the parts to replace the manual release assembly. On the afternoon prior to this the pilot informed me that he needed to phone the company immediately or it would cause big problems down the road. He offered no further explaination. I believe that the maintanence deficency was discovered by the pilot the day before. The helicopter manager was never informed of any of this and the problem went undectected by the crew until the hook checks were down prior to starting the helitorch operation.

While performing initial attack activities on the Cypress Creek Fire, the pilot had to land at the helispot for additional fuel. Once the refueling was complete, the pilot was to return to the fire to perform bucket drops.When the pilot initiated the starting sequence, the engine failed to start. The pilot attempted a second time to start the engine and it once again failed to start. With a second failure, the pilot decided not to try again until the problem was looked at by a mechanic. At this time, I informed the pilot that I did not hear the usual 'clicking' sound that the ignitor makes on a normal start. About this time, the mechanic for a Bell 212 assigned to the fire arrived at the helispot. The pilot, which is also the owner of the aircraft, asked the mechanic to take a look at the helicopter to see if he could find out what was causing the engine not to start. The mechanic started by removing the ignitor plug to see if it might have some carbon built up on the end, not allowing it to operate properly. Once it was removed, I, along with the mechanic and the pilot, observed only a small amount of carbon deposits on the end of the ignitor. The ignitor was cleaned and replaced in the engine, and the security wire was replaced. The pilot then tried to start the engine resulting another failed start.At this time, I made a call to Region-8 maintenance inspector Bill McMillan to inform him of the situation. With very poor cellular service on my end of the call, I was able to understand him enough to hear that it was alright to proceed, but that when I was able to get to a hard line phone, I was to call him and let him know what had happened.I knew that the mechanic was not a 407 mechanic, but I did allow him to proceed because what he was doing, in my opinion, did not warrant the necessity of a 407 mechanic. I was later informed by Mr. McMillan that this should not have been allowed because the 407 is such a new type aircraft and  that with the 'FADEC' system problems that occur might not be what they seem and need to be checked out by a qualified 407 mechanic.--Lesson learned.  The mechanic then decided to try and clean the fuel nozzle to see if this would help the situation. Once this was done, another attempt was made to start the engine which proved to be successful.The helicopter started each time necessary the rest of the day without fail. The pilot/owner of the aircraft decided to fly his mechanic in to take a look at the helicopter. The mechanic was at the helibase the next morning, Wednesday, April 21. He added a shim to the fuel nozzle and checked out the aircraft.  The aircraft started without incident. A call was made to Bill McMillan to inform him of the situation.  Mr. McMillan released the aircraft for work and told me that if the problem occurred again, that I was to make the aircraft unavailable and stop it from working. Once we were released to work we were dispatched back to the fire. When the pilot tried to start the engine, it once again failed to start. When this occurred, the mechanic tried changing out the ignitor plug and adding another shim to the fuel nozzle. This proved to be ineffective. At this time, I declared the helicopter unavailable and made a call to Mr. McMillan to keep him apprised of the situation.

Mission - fly to a remote gravel pit and use it as a base of operations for aerial ignition RX burning ops nearby. What happened - Enroute to gravel pit, the securing nylon strap for the Plastic Sphere Dispenser {PSD} slipped through the buckle and about 8 feet of the strap was ripped out of the cabin by the air friction on the strap and consequentially, the strap dangled under the belly of the ship during the remainder of the flight. Pilot could see the strap with the skid mirror and determined there was no factor with the tail rotor. Background - The PSD machine was secured to the floor of the aircraft with a seat belt-size nylon strap that ties one side of the PSD to the other by routing the strap under the door around the belly of the ship and back to the opposite side of the PSD machine. The buckle had blunt or rounded ''alligator teeth'' that were supposed keep the strap from loosening. In this case the buckle allowed the strap to slip through.

While conducting a PSD mission on the X prescribed fire the PSD machine abruptly stopped firing. The operator noticed the machine was not dropping balls. A power loss was noticed on the dispensing part of the machine and the cockpit was notified of a problem. A number 2 circuit had popped. The operator looked and pulled the fuse, the fuse appeared in working condition and was reinserted. The operator then attempted to clear the chutes manually but the machine was locked. Then the operator pushed in the fuse which turned the indicator lights back on briefly but did not turn the crank. The operator pressed the water button as a precaution. There was no smoke or any indication of an ignited PSD balls in the machine. The operator, burn boss and pilot decided to land the helicopter at the nearest landing zone. An attempt was made to get the manual assist dial to turn but there was no success. The ship flew back to helibase and the machine was removed from the aircraft. Outside the helicopter the manual assist was turned with more leverage and freed the machine. The machine was reattached to the helicopter and performed without error. There were no more PSD missions that day. There were no jammed balls in the machine at any point. The problem leads itself to a mechanical seizure. Prior to the incident there was a very thorough briefing conducted at the helibase to include all required documentation. The machine was bench tested prior to the operation. There was excellent Crew Resource Management established with the flight crew to include the contractors. Emergency procedures were followed and the training and trust that were established may have helped prevent a more serious incident.

May 16, 2001During flight operations over the Hurst Hammock fire the air attack pilot and the ATGS observed an intruder helicopter at their altitude (2000 ft MSL).  Sudden maneuvering was required to avoid collision.  The intruder aircraft then descended to 1500 ft and into the path of the lead plane.  The lead plane pilot then maneuvered to avoid collision and contacted ARTCC and asked if they were working a helicopter in the vicinity of the TFR over the fire.  ARTCC stated that they were not.  Lead maintained visual contact with the intruder aircraft and tanker operations were suspended until the intruder departed.  The aircraft maneuvered unpredictably in the vicinity of the fire, following the participating aircraft.  Positive identification was made that the intruder was a media helicopter and it was determined that he/she was maneuvering to photograph firefighting operations.  At one point the intruder departed the fire to film a fire-fighting helicopter dip water and then he/she chased the firefighting helo at the same altitude to the drop site.  All fire-fighting operations were ceased and the intruder departed.  Lead followed the intruder to class C airspace (approximately 2 mile to the East) and ensured that approach control had radar contact with the intruder aircraft.  Lead then coordinated with the fire and ATC to return to Pensacola Regional Airport to meet with the ARTCC supervisor.

After arriving to Cascade, ID from completing a mission on the bolder creek fire, the pilot and myself were advised that a potential hail storm was moving into the area. After refueling in Cascade to potentially fly to Boise, our alternate landing base, we received a mission from Cascade ID BOF to deliver food to the bolder creek fire. After discussing the incoming weather with the pilot, we decided we could complete the mission as it would take us out of the area, away from tracking storm, and allow us to circum navigate to Boise from the east/southeast. After the cargo mission was completed, we flight followed with Boise dispatch and asked for a weather update for the Ola helibase, our originally destination. They advised us of the same storm and suggested we not fly to Ola helibase. After discussing this with the pilot, we both concurred that the best course of action would be to continue to circumnavigate the storm to the east/southeast and continue to Boise. As we continued to circumnavigate the storm, we received an inflight weather briefing advising us of the storm tracking over the Ola helibase/Cascade area. During this time the weather was bumpy, there was no precipitation, and the visibility was 8-10 miles. About 40 miles out from Boise, we had a sudden on set of heavy rain. The exact words out of my mouth were “I hope that’s not hail,” and no later then finishing that sentence did we get hit by hail. The pilot immediately maneuvered the aircraft to the east and to a lower altitude, we continued to receive heavy rain for about another 15 -30 seconds before it ended. The whole incident lasted about a minute, from onset of rain to getting out of the hail. The flight continued to be bumpy but no other forms of precipitation was encountered for the rest of the flight. The first noticeable damage to the aircraft was the broken bubble window on the left door of the aircraft. After landing at Boise airport, the pilot, mechanic, and crew looked over the aircraft for damage. Damage to the aircraft consisted of the broken bubble window, divots in the skin on the nose, primarily isolated on the batter hatch cover, minor divots on the horizontal stabilizers leading edge, and divots on the upper vertical stabilizer. I notified my COR and Boise dispatch of what occurred. The pilot notified the company and further inspections by the OAS AMD’s will take place before becoming available for fire assignment.

On August 21st while returning from a recon of the Williams Butte fire on a Type 3 helicopter assigned to the fire, we spotted a jump ship flying up valley over the Foster Helibase. Immediately following, we saw a parachute in the trees below and another chute in the air at about 11 o’clock ahead. The pilot took immediate action turning to our right to avoid any additional conflict with the jumpers. Our flight path between Foster Helibase and the Williams Butte Fire was in constant use by as many as 11 helicopters on that date. The Williams Butte Fire had 4 type 1’s, 4 type 2’s, and 3 type 3’s. No communications were made by Wenatchee Dispatch (CWICC), the Smokejumper Base (NCSB), on a victor frequency by the jumpship to Foster helibase regarding the NCSB mission. Corrective Action: When a team is managing an incident on a Forest or other jurisdiction, close communication must be maintained between that jurisdiction’s aviation resources and the incident. Local jurisdiction on Initial Attack activities in the flight path of IMT aviation activities must be closely monitored. Frequencies need to be shared and commo exercised to ensure all aircraft are aware of others in the area. Somkejumpers should be assured that no other aircraft are in the same airspace

A type two helicopter with 100’ LL was requested for bucket work and departed the Helibase for the fire at 14:40. It took approximately 25 to 30 minutes of flight time for the pilot to arrive at the division and dip-site that was being worked on. 

The helicopters altitude was above 9500 MSL and wind appeared to be relatively strong 10+ MPH. As the pilot filled the first bucket, the aircraft climbed normally.  The Pilot was in contact with the A/G to pre-treat an area prior to a burn operation.  As the aircraft climbed the Pilot saw the strobe for the intended drop zone.  As the aircraft turned downwind, the airspeed deteriorated so the pilot aborted the drop by flying forward to gain airspeed.  As the airspeed increased the altitude decreased where the bucket caught a tree limb prior to completing the pullout.  The Pilot did not notice the bucket contact the trees as the bucket was aligned between the tree line along a road.  The pilot turned out and picked up the strobe to complete the drop

Upon being ordered for bucket work on division golf on the Bison fire the exclusive use helitack crew hooked the 240 gallon bucket to the belly of the aircraft. All the checks where done properly and the pilot was given the go ahead to begin a scheduled power check of the aircraft. During the power check the winds at the helibase were very gusty. When the power check was completed the pilot was given the go ahead to lift for his mission. Upon lifting the marshaller of the aircraft noticed the safety cable being pulled tight. The mashaller then notified the pilot to put the aircraft back down. When the crew came in to assess the problem, the crew noticed the powerhead of the bucket had cracked into two pieces, leaving the clevis still hooked to the belly of the aircraft and the rest of the powerhead hanging free form the safety cable. The electrical connection to the belly was not affected by the breaking/crack of the powerhead.

While performing large fire support on the Incident, an oil leak was discovered. Oil was dripping out of the valve and pooling in the carriage. 7/2/04 This narrative is an ammendment to the SAFECOM filed for this helicopter on 6/30/2004 (submitted by Helicopter Manager). Narrative: While performing a longline hookup I noticed a couple of puffs of white smoke come out of the left side cowl. I immediately had the pilot land and shut down the A/C. Upon inspection a leak was discovered on the breather tube flange that returns excess oil to the exhaust to be burned off. After discussion with the pilot it was determined that the helicopter needed to be repaired and that it would become un-available. I discussed the problem with my HELB(t) and we decided one of us needed to return to helibase to begin working on getting the helicopter repaired. The HELB(t) flew to helibase with the A/C. While I had confidence in the judgement of the pilot that the leak did not jeopardize the safety of the flight, I should have not asked the HELB(t) to fly down with the ship. This was a MAJOR oversight on my part. Policy dictates that when a problem is discovered that the A/C becomes unavailable @ that point. Once unavailable NO government personnel should be transported until the A/C is returned to service by an appropriate maintenance inspector.

Pilot reported low torque, inspection revealed fuel stream from P1 port in the inlet.  P1 bellows cracked.  Removed fuel control, installed fuel control with Allied Signal 1330.2 manual, chapter 73.  Put back into contract availability by the Regional Aviation Maintenance Inspector.
After landing to get the helitorch barrel refilled the pilot got out of the helicopter with the blades still turning and power to them to go to the bathroom.
19:00 hrs on July 7 2009, After Flying 4.4 hrs durring the shift the starters on the S64E failed to engage long enough for the engine to start. Failure of the electrical interlocks to stay engaged.

Flight departed Prineville for lightning holdover detection. Radios tested out fine while on the ground and in the air. 15 minute check-insnormal until A/C switched to another mountain top (repeater) at which point contact was lost with dispatch. A/C could hear us(dispatch)but we could not hear the A/C. A lookout reported within seconds of our routine check-in that recon was replying. A/C switched to another frequency and commo was restored. We decided to return the A/C to Prineville to check out radio system. Examination of the radio (King EPH - Alpha-numeric and Sigtronics intercom system) revealed frequency and tone were properly programmed and intercom working fine. Radio techs notified of possible problem at repeater site.
Landing gear disagreement light remained on when gear was selected during landing. Aircrew visually checked down lock indicators which showed safe and landed aircraft.

During shutdown of the aircraft, the pilot turned the aircraft off accidentally and then immediately tried to restart.  This action caused the engine to overheat.  The aircraft was taken out of service and the engine is being pulled and inspected.

We lifted off the Helibase headed for a reported smoke.  When we got inthe air we smelled fuel in the cabin.  We returned back to the Summit, landed and checked for any leaks.  We didn't find any and lifted off the helibase.  When we lifted off, we could smell the fumes agin. the ship returned back to the base and shut down.  When the pilot was shutting the ship down he noticed the fuel pressure guage wasn't going down.  The pilot and mechanic checked out the system and called the maintenence at the home office.  They checked the system again and took the ship for a maintenance test flight.  The system was working correctly and the smell of fumes were found to be from a saw bag in the cargo hold.

After coming in and refueling, helicopter left pad in route back to dip site when he realized that the fuel cap had not been reinstalled. Helicopter returned back to pad and fuel man went out and reinstalled the fuel cap. Helicopter then proceeded back on his mission, no sight of any fuel spill.

Duplicate of 14-0414.  Aircraft was performing bucket operations on the Fire with a 100 ft. synthetic long line and 160 gal. FAST Bucket. Making descending left turns in steep terrain the aircraft went into the dip-site. Pilot watched the bucket fill and began to ascend. Pilot felt the aircraft `want to roll` and corrected for the issue initially. Realizing something was wrong pilot set bucket back into dip and looked in mirror to see the long line over the heel of the left skid. Pilot released water from bucket to minimize roll over effect and slowly pulled up out of the dip. Pilot contacted the IC on A/G, notified him of the issue and asked if there was someone at the helispot that could remove the line from the skid. Pilot flew at a reduced airspeed to the fires helispot where a helitack crew was present and mitigated the problem. While being more cautious going into the dip and monitoring the mirror closely, pilot finished fuel cycle and returned to helibase. Once on the ground Pilot notified HMGB and FAO of what had happened.

While doing bucket operations on the South Fork fire the second in command pilot noticed that the aft LCT was not functioning properly. The ship ceased bucket operations and returned to the Mariposa airport, at approximately 1800. This is the fourth time that the aft LCT has failed on this aircraft since the 13th of July 2017. Talking with region 5 maintenance inspector and the aircraft COR it was determined that a SAFECOM should be filed to inform other Boeing CH47D users of this potential problem. Three of the four failed LCT have been from the same repair station.

While conducting retardant operations I descended below a ridge crossing altitude. This was NOT on purpose. I tunnel visioned the drop, and continued down. This was a little fill in spot and I was really focused on finishing the line. As I stated, this was NOT on purpose. We{crew} debriefed and talked about what happened, and of course, how to prevent this type of screw up. Thanks

At 1110, rotor ____ was working a MOB fire (urban interface with homes, structural engines in close proximity and mutiple access points). The incident was recorded on video phone.

Mechanic cleaned torque control unit, found only a small amount of soot, reassembled and conducted test flight. No problem encountered during test flight. Helicopter brought back in service and wound up for a mission with two passengers. Torque split of 20 % registers before any pitch is pulled. Mission is aborted and mechanic gets on for another test flight -- also searches for air leak -- finds no obvious leaks. Aircraft shut down, made unavailable. New torque control unit sent for. Note: Previous Safecoms filed 6/22, 6/23 for same problem. Up to this last incident the vendor's position has been that inisolatedin torque splits of 20% or better are not a grounding condition, poor communication between pilot, mechanic and manager (myself) contributed to some confusion initially over whether problem was a mechanical fault or pilot error (i.e. backing off on #2 throttle accidentally). Pilot error eventually proved not to be the case.

Working on the Long Mesa Fire in Mesa Verde NP, was approached by Type 3 Operations Section Chief, who wanted to talk to me about a previous flight he had taken two days before.  He stated that he didn't appreciate me asking him the nature of his flight when he arrived at the helibase, or if his passengers were necessary to the mission. He stated that he didn't know how much experience I had in fire or aviation, but that I should know enough to know that his position in itself is enough to validate any flight without question.  He stated that as inOperationsin, if he orders it, then it's necessary.  I replied that in the performance of my job, it is my duty to all passengers as well as the pilot to do a risk analysis of each mission, and part of that analysis is asking questions to ensure there is not a more appropriate ground alternative to the flight.  I stated that it's in our policy to ask inIs this flight necessary?in  inHave ground alternatives been considered?in  inAre all passengers necessary to the mission?in  I stated with this year's increased accident occurrence, I was even more scrutinizing of every mission to ensure a safe flight for everyone.  After hearing my reply, he stated again that as inOperationsin, if he orders a flight then it is necessary without question.  Conversation was terminated due to a fire dispatch.

NXXXX with Manager onboard landed at the Pine Airport after returning from Boise, ID for fuel.  In flight I advised the two Helitack crew members at the Pine Airport that NXXXX would land and we would connect the bucket and longline with rotors turning.Upon landing myself and the crew members connected the bucket and performed the manual and electrical checks for the hook and the bucket successfully. After initial attacking a fire on forest, my pilot and I went about providing bucket support with the aircraft. I rolled out the line and bucket, rigged it to the ship, and went through the checks. The ship lifted with no apparent problems and dipped water at an adjacent dip site. After taking on a load of water, the line came free of the ship and went to the bottom of the small lake. The pilot landed the ship and we located the bucket in 15 feet of water and we were able to recover the bucket to shoreline. There was no damage to the contractor hardware. The electrical coupling came apart with no damage to the aircraft. After reviewing the events of the afternoon, it was determined that the ground conditions at the landing site were not suitable for a reliable hook check. The ground was soft enough that the belly hook tongue was in contact with the soft mossy surroundings we were parked in. I was mistaken in thinking the hook was reset and locked.

After being dispatched to the 58 Fire I asked for other aircraft assigned to the fire. I was informed two airtankers and air attack 490 were on scene. As per normal operations I tried to contact air attack 10 miles from the fire. I tried at least seven times to contact air attack on the assigned victor frequency for the area. I then tried my air-to-ground frequency assigned to this area with the same results. I finally contacted air attack on Air Tactics. I informed him we would be on victor because of airtankers on the TAC frequency. Air attack asked what the victor frequency was for the area. I informed him several times our pilot could not reach air attack because he was on Kern Co. UHF frequency most aircraft in the Interagency world do not have this capability. Communications are essential to safety. Before aircraft launch they better have a good idea of what frequencies are to be used in what area.

On duty at 0900, this would be day 3 for mission over site for the Fire within the Zone. At 0920 we did a aircraft systems check before departure and all ops normal, at 0941 we departed airport for the incident with: two souls, 4 1/2 hours of fuel, on a heading 214 degree`s for a 22 min, ETE to the incident. at this point all operations were normal and during this time was calculating the times for relief air attack over the fire. At 12 miles from incident contacted IA helicopter on victor for entry into the airspace of the fire TFR in place, we proceeded into the area at 10,000 dropping to 9,000 ft all ops normal. Established ground contact with operations and IC for operational update and reconfiguration of divisions from the previous day. ordered up fixed wing aircraft: 2 seats for retardant line across the west flank of the fire towards the head. All ops normal. about 3 3/4 hours into the flight the pilot noticed that the fuel use gauge that reads pounds of fuel used per sec was not operational for the right engine, the engine never quit running. The pilot re-calculated the weights and measures for passenger, fuel and cargo, determined that it was either a gauge failure or sending unit and we had plenty of fuel. At 1348 air attack relief was over the fire, did a brief on the tactics and division break downs and handed off to the relief air attack. We proceeded back to The designated base, all ops normal except for the faulty reading of the right fuel/use gauge. Landed safely, notified UAM and Dispatch that aircraft was unavailable due to gauge failure.

Helicopter NXXXXX showed up at Minden airport per instructions to meet up withhis Helicopter Mgr before going to the Genoa Fire which was only two miles away. No Manager was present so he contacted Minden Dispatch through the Air Tanker Base personnel and was told to proceed to the Genoa fire where his Mgr was supposed to be waiting. He proceeded to the fire and was told to go back to the airport and stand by. The fire called and said they wanted him back there so he hooked up his bucket and went to the Genoa fire where he made about 30 drops before being released back to the Minden airport. The next day he was dispatched to another USFS fire down by Markleeville and proceeded there to work the fire. On shut-down from the first fuel cycle of bucket work on the fire, I exited the left seat and visually checked the left side of the aircraft for any leaks. The co-pilot exited the right seat. Since the fire was still active and more bucket work was needed, I did not open any cowlings, as we frequently do when we shut down this model helicopter for refueling. I then went to the right side of the aircraft to monitor refueling. Some time during the refueling procedure, the co-pilot opened the left side engine cowl and left it open. After the refueling was complete, I checked the fuel cap, looked at the right side of the aircraft for any leaks and asked the co-pilot if he was ready to go. He indicated he was ready to go, so I walked around the nose of the aircraft and climbed in the left door to strap in the left seat for the start. The co-pilot strapped in the right seat. The left side lower engine cowl, when open, cannot be seen from the front door without stepping away from the aircraft a few steps, which I had not done. After a normal start, we lifted off and proceeded toward the fire, about 4 miles away, to resume bucket work. Firefighters on the ground called on the radio and informed us that there was an open cowl. Apparently, the co-pilot had forgotten about the open cowl until the radio call was received. I immediately landed, inspected the cowl to make sure it was not damaged, secured it and then uneventfully continued the mission. As pilot-in-command, I did not adhere to a vital safety precept that I usually use, which is: Always make one quick walk-around inspection around the whole helicopter prior to climbing in to start it. Deficient communication and inadequate Crew Resource Management (CRM) between the pilot and co-pilot also contributed to this incident.

We started the RX burn around 12:30. Everything was going fine with no problems. After about 1 1/2 hours of firing we went back to the helispot to refuel, eat, and warm up. We were down approximately 30 minutes. We left the helispot around 14:48 to finish the RX burn. We had been firing about 20 minutes when all of a sudden the machine lost power. I immediately told the ignition boss and the pilot that the machine had lost power and I was accessing the problem. I closed the feed control and turned the control panel to the off mode. I looked to make sure the power cable hadn`t come loose. Everything was connected. I started turning the manual assist to get any balls out of the exit chute. A couple of balls exited but I was having problems turning the manual assist. At that time I noticed a glow around the feed control and exit chute. I immediately pushed the water button on the control panel extinguishing the fire. At that point I told the pilot and ignition boss that I had to use water to extinguish the fire, we still had no power and we needed to go back to the helispot. We landed at the helispot at 15:25. Once we took the hopper off we saw that the third needle had been bent up and to the right and there were two balls jammed in the block. Were the needle was bent this was not allowing me to use the manual assist which caused the fire. We replaced the needle and once that was done then the plunger/guide would not move.

I recieved a dipatch and departed AVQ at 1343 for the Black fire. Initial contact was made with ATGS Trainee XX about 20 miles out and I picked up flight folowing with him. At 11 miles I again contacted ATGS and was cleared into the fire at 2500 ft. MSL. I arrived on the fire at the same time as Lead XX and ATGS turned me over to Lead. I followed Lead for a couple of circuits of the fire and a ''show me'' at which time I ws cleared for the drop and competed the first half of the drop across the head of the fire. Lead continued up and to the right in a wide pattern. I told lead that I stil had half a load and would continue my turn to pick up the dogleg down the flank. Lead acknowledged and said he was wide. Having dropped half of the load and light I was able to turn lower and inside Lead and continued the turn to pick up the final. As we were converging Lead said he as going to cross the saddle higher on the ridge and ''look at the line'', at this pont I had him in sight and reported that I was inside and below him. Lead reported me ''insight''. As I turned final I could not see Lead as my wing was up, but was comfortable as Lead was outside to my left, well above and had me insight. I did not see Lead at any time after turning final. After the drop I continued straight out at drop altitude over flat terrain befre climbing as I believed Lead to be above and behind me. I heard someone say ''that was a little close'' and Lead responded ''yes a little''. I had no Idea what was being disscussed. On departure I was instructed to load and return. I picked up flight following with State Fire and returned to AVQ and reloaded.Returning turning to the fire I contacted ATGS at 12 miles and was cleared into the fire at 2500. I reported again at 5 miles and was instructed to hold southwest untill the helicopter completed his drop and departed. After the Helicopter complete his drop I was cleard in and completed 3 split drops under direction of ATGS. After the drop I returned to AVQ to hold. Other than the remark of ''that was a lttle close'' there was no other discussion of what was close.

During bucketing operations on the fire, we were assigned a mission on the right flank: with the assurance from Air Attack that the multiple SEATs would remain over the left flank.  While at the dip, we observed a SEAT flying at our altitude {1600’} directly over our drop zone on the right flank, approximately 1/4 mile or less from our dip site.  I immediately called Air Attack on the Victor and told him the SEAT was not where he was supposed to be.  Air Attack then instructed the SEAT to fly his pattern in the opposite direction so as not to overfly the right flank.  We had previously heard the Air Attack instruct the SEATs to stay on the left flank and not overfly the right, where the helicopter was working.  The sky was clear, and there did not seem to be a need for the SEAT in question to fly over the right flank.  A second SEAT, shortly thereafter, overflew the right flank after being instructed not to, but at 2500’, not at our level.

While doing an operational rappel on the fire to cut in a heli-spot: after both sticks of rappellers had reached the ground and moved clear from the rappel site and cargo site, The helicopter made a couple of laps around the spot while the spotter configured cargo {two fire boxes and one 5 gallon cubee}. The pilot and spotter got set up over the cargo spot well away from the rappellers on the ground. The first load of cargo got to the ground without incident. The pilot felt good with the spot so he held hover as the spotter got the second load of cargo ready {two fire boxes and one 5 gallon cubee}. Once the cargo was rigged and ready, the spotter checked the spot to ensure the ship had remained over the site. After confirming power was good, the spotter started to deploy the cargo. The cargo was out of the door, with both fire boxes clear of the outside of the skids, but the 5 gallon cubee got hung up on the inside of the skid. The spotter then locked off the let down line on the ears of the figure 8 and worked to free the cubee from inside the skid. When the spotter was finally able to pull the cubee up and over the skid, both the cubee and the saw box came undone from the let down line and fell to the ground about 150ft. The spotter then unlocked the let down line and lowered the remaining cargo box to the ground without incident.

In the early hours of Aug 8, 2000 two engines were parked parallel to a two track road (Pulled off to the right side of the road one engine behind the other).  One USFS crewperson was asleep on a cot about 6-8 feet from the engine on the opposite side of the fire.  The other crewpersons were either between the engines or in the cabs. At approximately 0400 a dozer that was working the fire was attempting to relocate to another area on the fire and was driving down the same two track road.  Because the engines were blocking part of the road the dozer left the two track and went around the engines.  His inside track hit the cot the crewperson was sleeping on and woke him up.  He crewperson rolled off the cot and escaped injury. (He did later complain about a sore calf and hip and thinks he was hit by the blade of the dozer. X-rays were taken at a local hospital and he was released).  The dozer's track rolled over and crushed the cot and the dozer operator proceeded to the fire line to continue working, never aware that the incident occurred.The crewperson received a Critical Stress Debriefing at 1700 on 08-08-00 and was back to work on 08-09-00.
The number one engine was started with the tail-cone {exhaust} cover installed. No damage or injury.

While conducting prescribed burn activities on 6 different days the Premo PSD machine experienced a blockage of at least one of the chutes on each of the dates. The blockage was from separated spheres that had become attached to another sphere {see photo}. On the first occasion the PSD operator noted that the bag of spheres seemed to have some residue on the outside of the sphere, seemingly from the potassium permanganate of the broken sphere.. The other dates this did not seem to be the issue, as the spheres were clean on the outside. Noted when cleaning the machine on these dates the PSD machine had a fine covering of potassium permanganate on the slipper blocks, cams, and needle area. The broken sphere becomes attached to a viable sphere and this larger shape allows the unit to enter into the chute but then becomes lodged in the chute. The only way to vacate the chute is to remove the hopper and to push the sphere unit from below.

On 8/23/00 at 1830 hrs. while conducting smokejumper operations on the Cameo Fire, BLM Grand Junction District, a smokejumper landed in an inactive portion of the fire.  The jumper was the first person of the second stick when the incident occurred.Jump conditions at the time were; winds @ 7mph, jumpspot size @ 2 acres and upwind of fire with no hazards in the spot, slope flat, thunderstorm @ 2 miles to the east, first two jumpers landed in spot and informed plane that jump conditions were acceptable.  Fire behavior was inactive with retardant inhibiting fire spread.  Fire size was 3 acres.During descent, winds increased and prevented the jumper from making the intended jumpspot.  Jumper was forced past the jumpspot and landed going backwards into the black, where some embers burnt several small holes in the parachute before removing it from the burned area.  No other equipment nor the jumper received any burns.Jumper suffered a left shoulder sprain during the landing and was taken to Grand Junction for examination.  Jumper has been placed in light duty status and should be able to perform full duties within 5 days.

inThis airplane is shaking real bad and I don't know why!in  That is the first thing Lead heard after the tanker dropped his first two doors on the fire.The time was about 1700 on 8/7/01.  It was the tanker's second trip to the fire.  Lead arrived at the fire just as the tanker completed his first drop.  The decision to load and return was made and when the tanker returned, Lead conducted the normal brief and provided a show-me run on that same spot fire a helicopter had been working on.  Getting to the drop site required a significant descent which put Lead way down in the valley, so it took a long time to climb out.  The tanker asked where Lead was and at the same time announced he was on a base to the drop.  The tanker continued with the run and Lead could see him on the base leg turning final.  Lead watched the two door drop.  Not long after the tanker was on the exit he made the radio call, inThis airplane is shaking real bad and I don't know why!in  Lead immediately told the tanker to punch off the remainder of the load which he did.  The tanker captain said it felt like the airplane was in a stall.  Not long after that, the captain announced he found the problem to be the life boat access door on top of the left wing between the left engine and fuselage had come open.  At the end of the valley on the exit a right turn was required.  Lead informed the tanker to turn right at the end of the valley as briefed earlier.  The captain said he had to go left because the tanker wouldn't turn right.  Lead said, inYou have to turn rightin.  The only way out was right unless enough altitude was gained to clear the ridges that formed the bowl if a left turn was made.  After retracting some flaps, the tanker captain informed Lead that the shaking wasn't as bad and that he could turn right.After having successfully negotiated the exit, Lead informed the tanker that he would follow him to landing.  The initial decision to go to Coeur'd Alene was scrapped after the tanker captain decided that the airplane flew better with no flaps.  Due to construction on the runways at Coeur'd Alene, there wasn't a long enough runway to accomodate a no flap landing.  Lead informed the tanker that his options were Spokane Intl. (GEG) or Fairchild Air Force Base.  The tanker decided GEG. About 40 miles out from Spokane, Lead contacted Spokane Tower and declared an emergency for the tanker.  The tanker made a no flap approach and landing and a one engine reverse landing roll with the opposite engine.  The landing was uneventful.

Upon coming in to land at the airport the convex cargo mirror came off approximately 10-15 feet above the ground. The mirror bounced off the ground and rolled forward onto the asphalt under the rotor wash. After the helicopter landed and shut down, a further inspection of the mirror bracket arm revealed that the attachment point had snapped off where the mirror was mounted. A discussion with the mechanic determined that the mirror and bracket arm were likely the originals from the helicopter`s manufacture dated 2001. The articulating arm was subjected to the normal vibrations of the aircraft, which over time may have weakened the connection point.

N1048Y was doing fire suppression bucket work on the Togo fire.  Ship was dipping water out of a 15,000 gallon heli-well with a Griffith bucket, at an established dip site about 2 miles south-east of the fire.  Ship had dipped out of the heli-well, and was beginning to depart the dip site when winds changed unfavorably. Consequently, ship had insufficent power/lift, so pilot dumped part of the water cargo.  The bucket came near (6-8 feet) to hitting ground as pilot was trying to regain lift, but the bucket did not hit ground.  The bucket was still part full (1/3 to 1/2) when pilot regained sufficient lift.  With a partially loaded bucket, pilot maneuvered ship back to the heli-well to again fill to capacity.  As pilot was positioning bucket over the heli-well to top it off to capacity, the partially loaded bucket came down on the rim of the heli-well.  The weight of the rigid bucket and water cargo buckled two panels of the heli-well, bending the panels inward, causing a slight overhang in the dip tank diameter.  Resulting damage may require replacing these two panels, if they cannot be bent back into shape.Note that damage only occurred to the heli-well, with no damage to N1048Y ship.

On the afternoon of July 5, the HMGB of a Type 1 heli-tanker advised his pilot of a weather service warning for severe thunderstorms with quarter-sized hail and to “baton things down.” The company rep, the ASGS, and the HMGB got into a discussion about whether flying to avoid the storm would be revenue or non-revenue. This occurred at the box on the helibase, about ¼ mile from the helicopter pad. The ASGS said that nobody was ordering the helicopters to move, so if the company decided there was an eminent threat, it was there decision to do so and the flight would be non-revenue. After the discussion, the HMGB drove down to the pad. When the HMGB got to the pad, he said the helicopter spooled up and was lifting off before he got out of the truck. The HMGB reported afterward that he did not know if the aircraft had communication with anyone, as the wind of the coming storm along with radio chatter prevented him for knowing for sure. The HMGB was also unsure of how many souls were on board at that time {1830}. After the incident, neither the personnel at the helibase {HMGB, ASGS, or others}, or dispatch knew SOB/FOB for the ship. At 1720, the incident HB got a call from the Helitanker: “Off HB to Torrington: will contact Casper.” The aircraft desk noticed a Type 1 helicopter go positive AFF at 1724. At first, the desk thought it was a local fire mission. By 1730, the two dispatchers were discussing the craft and its mission. They knew of nothing it could be doing that would take it to the east. Contact on National FF was attempted, and a message was left with the AOBD on the incident. Great Plains Dispatch was asked to contact the ship for mission, fuel, souls. They couldn`t reach them. About 1757, the ship went red on AFF. We again called Great Plains Dispatch Aircraft Desk. The ASGS was notified dispatch that had no contact with the ship and they had gone red on AFF. He said they were moving to avoid the storms. Meanwhile, dispatch called the Casper tower. The tower had not heard from the craft and informed Torrington was an unmanned strip. Dispatch called sheriff`s office and asked them to send an officer toward the airport. At 1802, AOBD called and said the helicopter was moving to avoid storms and was calling Air Support to see the status of the ship. At 1811, the GACC called to inquire on HT status. During that call, AOBD called back and informed all that the manager had contact with the pilot and everyone was alright. The airport tower, county law enforcement, the GACC, and the neighboring dispatch center involved were all notified of the situation. Per AOBD, an AAR will be scheduled to learn from this incident and avoid future communications issues.

Performing fire detection flight for Arizona Strip BLM at 11,500 AGL when an impact was felt in the floorboard region of the pilot and ATGS seats. Pilot immediately turned the plane north towards Richfield {29 minute ETE}. All gauges and both engines were functioning normal showing no fluctuation. ATGS trainee sitting front seat contacted Color Country Dispatch and advised that something had happened with the plane and we were inbound to Richfield to inspect but the plane was operating normally. An emergency was not declared nor warranted. Within 30 seconds of impact an odor was detected within the cabin. The odor was not electrical in nature but we looked over all the circuit breakers to see if there was a fault. All circuit breakers were engaged and there was no fault. Began a visual inspection of the parts of the plane that were visible from the cabin. ATGS trainer in backseat observed blood on the inboard side of the right engine nacelle. ATGS trainee from the front seat looked back and could also see blood along the underside of the wing on the inboard side. Assumption was made that it was a bird strike and we landed safely in Richfield.

At aprox 1254 March 14, 2010 the helicopter was spooling up at the Airport. In aircraft were Pilot, FIRB, and PLDO. HMGB was aprox 50 feet in front of aircraft as crash rescue/fire protection. Aircraft was configured for aerial ignition mission on NF. Pilot and HMGB established good communication on air to ground frequency as a routine and did so as aircraft spooled up. Left front door of aircraft was off at FIRB’s request with Pilot’s approval. Aircraft was at flight idle. After comm check HMGB heard FIRB seconds later, on air to ground say, “could you hold on to this” as FIRB was digging in his left front pocket. HMGB then made it two steps toward aircraft to take object from FIRB then heard a sharp noise followed by several other noises aprox twenty feet to left side of aircraft. HMGB then hand signaled pilot to shut aircraft down. Pilot did not fully understand so HMGB approached pilot door to tell him to shut down. Dispatch was notified there was a situation and aircraft would be unable to perform aerial ignition for RX burn. Pilot, FIRB, PLDO, and HMGB discussed what had just happened. A pocket knife was under-hand tossed by FIRB from aircraft toward HMGB, which made contact with one main rotor blade. FIRB had attempted to toss the knife in the grass just off the asphalt in front of aircraft to avoid anything falling from aircraft during flight. Upon contact with the rotor, the knife burst into pieces landing off to the left side of the aircraft. Pilot inspected blades finding place of impact. HMGB called and notified Regional maintenance inspector at 1305. Pilot contacted Helicopter’s mechanic at same time. HMGB notified COR/AFMO of situation at 1328, and FMO 1444. Helicopter mechanic arrived at aprox 1530 and performed inspection of blades and aircraft. Inspection revealed two small gashes aprox 9 inches from tip of one blade and aprox 2 millimeters deep on the leading edge. Also found were several small paint chips on underside of blade which did not enter “honey comb” of blade. Mechanic then spoke with Regional Maintenance Inspector and Helicopter operator’s Chief of Maintenance for directions. Aircraft will remain at airport for the night to allow mechanic time to obtain proper equipment for a possible repair.

The helicopter flew from Prineville Airport to the Crescent Airstrip with two helitack on board. The crew landed at Crescent Airstrip and hooked up the bucket. He looked down at the FM radio and the display was blank. The pilot was unable to transmit or receive on FM. He returned to the airstrip. The pilot could not fix the problem with the FM radio.

On April 13, 2010, helicopter was hired by NICC for the Walker fire on the Coronado NF. Flight plan was received and faxed to the affected dispatch offices. Upon getting word from NICC of actual departure from airport at 0715 on 4/14, SWCC noticed AFF was not active for the helicopter. SWCC instructed Albuquerque and Silver City Dispatch Centers to attempt to contact the helicopter on both NFF {168.150} and Air Guard {168.625} to confirm positive contact. These attempts were not successful. Silver City Dispatch Center transmitted to the helicopter that AFF was not active and positive contact via radio needed to be established. The helicopter was scheduled for a fuel stop in Safford, AZ before proceeding to the helibase in Tucson, AZ. AFF became active approximately 1 hour after takeoff and approximately 30 minutes prior to landing at Safford, AZ. Tucson Dispatch was briefed on the situation and instructed to brief the assigned helicopter manager on the situation. SWCC confirmed with Tucson Dispatch that positive radio contact was not established during the flight from Safford to Tucson either. Once on the ground at Tucson helibase, Tucson communicated with the pilot that no further flights would be conducted until positive radio contact could be established.
