While conducting ATGS operations on the Sawmill Incident, a light helicopter entered the TFR unannounced. Unable to contact the helicopter on the assigned VHF_AM Frequency of 122.425, I contacted East Idaho Dispatch Center and asked if they knew of a local helicopter that might be in the area, they responded that it was probably helicopter xxx and it should be on VHF-AM 136.225. I contacted the helicopter on 136.225 and asked why they didn't contact me on the assigned 122.425 frequency prior to entering the TFR. The pilot responded that East Idaho Dispatch Center had told him the fire frequency was 136.225 for the Sawmill fire, which was incorrect, and had cleared him to enter the fire area. I contacted EID and informed them they had given the helicopter the wrong frequency and asked them why they had cleared the aircraft to enter into the TFR. Their response was that they were told that there were no aircraft on the incident. I asked who told them that. After pausing, their response was ''you never notified us that you were going to fly'', I responded that my instructions were to flight follow with the Pocatello Helibase and also to keep the Air Tanker Base appraised of my status which I had complied with.  A review of the radio log at Pocatello ATB confirmed that EID was notified at 0834 that I had launched and was en-route to the Sawmill Incident.

On initial taxi, pilot noticed unusually high power settings(~15% to start moving), stopped, cycled the parking break a few times, noted normal taxi power settings and continued to the runway.  On the takeoff roll, pilot noted 10 kts below the local S-2 minimum acceleration check speed but elected to continue the takeoff.  At rotation and during the initial portion of the upwind leg, the pilot faintly smelled hot brakes then at ~500 feet lowered the gear to cool the brakes and prevent the possibility for a nacelle fire.  The pilot then cleaned up and jettisoned the retardant load at the nearest jettison area, declared an emergency with NORCAL In order to have crash response available at at KMCC and proceeds to KMCC in a dirty configuration to increase fuel burn and land light.  Pilot touched down as slow as possible.  Rollout and taxi to AMU were uneventful.  Pilot terminated emergency response with ARFF 1 while rolling out.

While flying an air attack mission, we exceeded 8 hours of flight time for the day. Our morning air attack shift was lengthy due to difficulty in arranging for a relief air attack, and our later shift in the afternoon and evening had several helicopters working the fire with areas of compromised visibility due to smoke. While the helicopter pilots operated professionally, I felt obligated to remain on scene as ground crews attempting to hold roads and dozer lines occasionally summoned air support toward areas of diminished visibility. In this situation, my focus became finding safe targets for the helicopters, and providing on-scene flight following. I allowed myself to lose focus on my own mission, however, and it was my pilot who noted with alarm that we had flown nearly 8 hours already. As we made this realization, the helicopters on scene reached the end of their fuel cycle and headed for the helibase. We closed out with the helicopters as we turned toward our home field. No other airports nearby would allow us to land before our flight time expired.

While performing a long line mission to personnel at a spike camp located near H-22 on the Farewell Fire, a daisy chained load was lost in transit. The load consisted of food, water and fuel at a weight of 1945 lob, and was in a standard, 2 net daisy chain configuration. The nets were made in adherence w/IHOG policy, and were not swinging or flying irregular according to cargo personnel and pilot accounts. 3 minutes after leaving the cargo loading area, the pilot felt the load release while flying up  a drainage toward the fire location north of the helibase. Upon returning to helibase, the pilot radioed to the pad, and asked for a visual inspection of the hook before it was placed on the ground at his pad. Visual inspection of the remote hook was done by myself and chief mechanic of the aircraft. All remote hook operations (checks) were performed, and found to be operational. The keeper gate also was found to be operational, which was thought to be the cause of a previously lost load during a previous mission w/a relief pilot (7/28/03). After a discussion w/pilot, mechanic and helibase manager, trouble shooting scenarios were discussed. The remote hook in question was tested and overhauled in March of 2003, and both lost loads ((7/28 and 8/2) had been several loads into the cargo missions. Both pilots (relief 7/28 and primary 8/2) reported that hand position on the cyclic did not correlate w/an inadvertent release of the loads. Upon further discussion of both scenarios, it was stated that both loads were lost in approx. the same location from cargo area. I also showed several scenarios where cross loading of smaller diameter rings will open the keeper gate of the remote hook. At the time of this writing, a call is in to MTDC specialist (XXX XXXXX) to the likelihood of this scenario, and the remote hook has been replaced as a corrective and/or preventative measure. Additional info will be provided at a later time.

On August 20, 2020 at 15:20 hours, Guard copter 802 hit it’s water bucket on a tree during a water dropping mission for the Butte Lightning Complex.  Guard copter 802 is a CH-47 with a 120’ longline attached to the bucket. The Lat/Long for the Cow Dip site is N 39 59.33 W 121 27.06.  We made contact with a tree while exiting a dip.  We were supporting fire “1-2”.  This was the second “dip” on a new fuel cycle.  Guard 802 had previously pulled 9 buckets from the this dip site on our first fuel cycle. 

The dip site is at an elevation of 6,200’.  The temperature was approximately 29 degrees.  Our speed over ground was 10 knots thus not into effective translational lift (ETL).  The bucket is a 2,000 gallon Tarantula Power-Fill Bambi bucket but was only 75% full.  We utilized the same exit path for departure from the pond each time.  The crew did not see the “snag” tree in time to jettison the water from the bucket and the bucket made contact with the top of the tree and tore a hole in the side of the bucket.  After briefing with the crew, it was determined/agreed that we did not climb enough altitude (AGL) prior to forward flight.  The tear is too large to patch and therefore out of service.  The crew of 802 did not feel anything in the aircraft when we struck the tree.  There was no other damage related to this incident.

The manager and the pilot discussed the issue and decided to land as soon as possible. They set down at the heel of Brown Butte Fire in a safe area. The manager instructed the two crewmembers to exit the aircraft to a safe area. The pilot tried to roll the throttle to idle, but the throttle stayed open at 100 percent. They then looked for popped breakers, none were found. The pilot could not shut down aircraft and we discussed the issue over the radio with the mechanic. The mechanic and pilot decided it would be best to fly to the Twin Falls Airport to further address problem. They made the decision for the manager to exit aircraft and drive to the airport. The pilot made it back to Twin Falls safely and was able to shut down by going into manual mode and shut the fuel down.

This safecom concerns fuel contamination on N3310 and N351WM. The story starts on 6/26/99 when N3310 had a fuel filter light on lift off from Jerome Airport. It was landed immediatly and a Idaho Helicopters mechanic was flown over and changed out the filter. N3310 was put back in service after a check with Jim Morrison and dispatched to the Massacre Rocks fire. No further problems until today 6/27/99 and 5.8 flight hrs. later. At 1300 hrs. N3310 had another fuel filter light. Mechanic for the company was in the area and was soon there. It was suspected that the pressure differential mechanism on the fuel filter was faulty as fuel samples out of the truck and helicopter appeared clear and bright. Mechanic had brought along a different whole fuel filter assembly and changed it out. Fuel samples out of truck and helicopter again checked and appeared good. Mechanic was suspicious of fuel in the filter cannistor, however outside the filter. N3310 was test flown and then fuel was sampled directly out of the filter. It appeared clear and bright. As this was going on N351WM had fueled from his truck and went to do tank work. After one drop he also had a fuel filter light and came back to helibase and shut down. N3310 was put back in service and flew about one hr. and fifteen minutes at which time he had another filter light and came back in and shut down. It became very apparent that both ships had been contaminated. They had each fueled out of their own trucks the whole time. It appears that both trucks, being set up the same, had done the same thing. Beyond the filter at the hose reel there is a grease zerk that was greased on HT 20 (for 310) at a previous time and on HT 10 (for 351WM) this morning. Somehow this allowed grease into the fuel hose, thus into the aircraft fuel tank and fuel system. One sample of fuel was intentionaly contaminated with grease and allowed to set for a couple of hours. After that time grease could obviously be seen in btm. of the jar. After second light on 310 I was unable to contact R-4 inspector or H.O.S. but did talk to C.O.R. and told him what had been done and we agreed to put helicopter back in service. Now F.S. and O.A.S. tech. reps are fully informed of both helicopters out of service. Awaiting fix to the problem. Fuel was also recirculated through both trucks so there is a possibilty that the tanks on both trucks could also be contaminated.

While enroute to a dipsite on a new, to us, part of the fire, air-attack commenced with a hand over briefing to the replacement air-attack on the rotor air to air. We were already in an area of somewhat limited visibility, in a canyon and looking for another aircraft. The briefing continued for an extended length of time, limiting our ability to communicate with, and locate, the other aircraft in the area, creating an unsafe flying environment. Soon after, we were close to dropping a bucket of water with ground personnel in the area, who we were in contact with, when air-attack started briefing a safety officer over the air to ground frequency. The briefing continued, without a break, until I cut in and informed them that the frequency was needed for making safe drops. With personnel on the ground under canopy, invisible from the air, I felt the frequency should be clear in case the ground personnel needed to contact me before dropping, for their safety in particular. The drop was not made until the frequency was clear. The air-attack then informed me that the air to ground was the only frequency he could use for his briefings, but he would try not to brief while we were over the drop zone. This seems to be a common problem that shouldn''t occur on an established fire with multiple frequencies.
APU failed to start.

Dispatched to South Pine Fire #1676, WA DNR @ 16:12 from KOMK,  with report of multiple structures immediately threatened. IA aviation resources initially assigned were ATGS, two AT-802 Fire Bosses, and a T2 Restricted Use helicopter. Upon arrival on scene, H-XXX was on ground at helispot , and preparing for bucket work. Contacted IC on A/G and confirmed aircraft tactical objectives to support ground resources engaging the fire. Cleared H-XXX to lift and work left flank from a dip site located adjacent and west of left flank. Cleared in the FB XXX and XXX to maneuver and drop on right flank . Directed Fire Bosses to go to a scoop site approx 10 miles to north of the fire. Cleared in FB XXX and XXX upon return to tag and extend from previous drop. As we (ATGS) were orbiting around heel of fire , ATGS saw 3 para gliders fly through FTA over the fire approx. 500-1000' below us on the right flank/east side of fire. We notified all A/C on scene of intrusion, and then observed the para gliders depart to the east and fly out over the main valley outside of the FTA. FB XXX and XXX were ordered to scoop and return after the drop. Upon their return, ATGS cleared them in to tag and extend on last drop on right flank. As ATGS plane was orbiting  right flank from north to south, pilot and ATGS saw one para glider fly over the top of our plane within 500'. We were at 5,000 MSL. Pilot looked to his left and saw the other two para gliders  below and left within 1,000' feet of our position . We flew straight south to avoid para gliders, then climbed to 7,000 MSL and orbited outside of the FTA. No TFR had been requested by ATGS prior to intrusion as we were only 30 minutes into the mission.

As we were coming in to the LZ, one of the crew members on the ground noticed something leaking by the fuel tank. Once we landed and shut the helicopter down the pilot came and examined the leak. He said it was for sure fuel and we needed to find out where it was coming from. The pilot looked into the engine a little more and found out it was leaking between the electric fuel shut off valve. The pilot pressurized the system with the boost pumps and could not recreate the leak. He returned to base without the helitack crew.

After flying on the Fire, we landed at the airtanker base. During the post flight inspection I noticed that the main cabin door would not close quite right. After further inspection it was noted that the right side of the main cabin door hinge was torn about six inches causing the aft portion of the door to close prior to the forward portion of the door. Maintenance was notified and concurred that the hinge needed to be replaced prior to flying the aircraft. A new hinge was ordered.

A medium helicopter assigned to the fire complex experienced difficulties while dipping with a bucket and long line which lead to a close call for the relief pilot. The first fuel cycle went smoothly according to the pilot, having chosen a dip site he was comfortable with. When he returned from a hot refuel, the aerial supervision platform had transitioned and specific dip sites were identified as appropriate. Upon attempting to use one of the new dip sites the aircraft `turned` due to erratic winds at which point he was able to recover. Having been shaken by the event, the pilot continued to attempt approaches at other dips but had difficulties in understanding where AA wanted him to dip. Due to the misunderstanding of directions and his unease with previous events, he made the decision to return to helibase and make himself unavailable for external load missions for the remainder of the shift. Erratic winds were present along with poor visibility creating less than ideal conditions. Other aircraft/pilots were successful with the dip sites and were more familiar with the local area and conditions.

On Saturday, 7-7-2012, an Air Attack platform arrived at the Navarre Fire at approximately 1330. We had been working this fire for two days utilizing the DNR Air-to-Ground frequency for communications during suppression activities. This air attack began using the frequency for his `In-Brief` to gather information for the fire, stating he did not have the tactical frequencies and interfered with our normal ground communications. CWICC was attempting to establish contact with him through Badger Repeater, which he did not have. The frequency was transmitted and he indicated he would program the radio. Later, when the air tankers arrived, he decided not to use their frequency but remain on the tactical DNR air-to-ground channel.

Subject:  SAFECOM - Canadian Bird Dog#52,           Left Engine Failure.At approximately 1100 hours MDT Canadian Bird Dog#52, a Turbo Commander, departed Miles City, Montana for Helena, MT.  After reaching cruising altitude of 12,500 feet westbound, and 25 minutes out of Miles City, the left engine suddenly lost power and went to auto feather.  There were no prior indications (instrumentation) that there was a problem developing.  After a cool down period of approximately 2 minutes, and attempt to restart the engine was made but immediately aborted due to no indication of oil pressure.The aircraft was under FS flight following with Lewistown as Billings could not be raised.  Flight following and position reports were also conveyed to Helena on FS nets.The aircraft had no difficulty maintaining altitude and was operating in CAVU conditions.  The flight crew made a judgement call to continue on to Missoula where they had maintenance support even though it was somewhat further than Helena where the logistics of repair would be difficult.  This decision was based on what the flight crew believed to be inpracticablein given the circumstances of clear air, no problems in maintaining altitude, other available landing places along the route, and the availability of maintenance support in Missoula.Bird Dog #52 continued west at 12,500 feet MSL with no further difficulties, other than reduced airspeed, and maintained visuals on airports and landing area's they could reach if problems developed with the right engine.Landing was affected in Missoula at near 1200 hours where they taxied to Northstar Aviation and met with their maintenance team.  The cowling was removed, screens pulled showing a lot of evidence of metal particle, i.e., steel and brass.  The engine had failed and required an engine change.USDA Forest Service LiaisonCanadian Airtanker Deployment

We, the smokejumper aircraft took runway 24 for takeoff and made our departure call on UNICOM.  Helitack helicopter said on UNICOM they were lifting from the ramp and would hold for our takeoff.  We started our takeoff roll and the helicopter departed to the north crossing runway 24 approximately 4,000 feet in front of us.  We called on UNICOM that we were already on our takeoff roll and the helicopter stated that they had us in sight.

Pilot flew into a sling site to retreive backhaul. Qualified helitack (smokejumpers) hooked the load to the cargo hook. The pilot inadvertantly released the longline from the helicopter, causing it to tumble to the ground (pilot was hovering slightly uphill from personnel while hooking, so the line fell uphill) He was unable to land, so he returned to the helispot while the jumpers topped a few trees to allow him to do a hover hook up. He returned to the sling spot, the load was reattached by hover hook up and he began flying back to the helispot. One half way back, the load, longline, and hook all disconnected from the helicopter. After some searching, the load was located, the location GPSed and retreived shortly after. The pilot admitted his error in mistakenly ''''punching off the load'''' the first time while he was looking down through the bubble. He is confident that he did not ''''punch off'''' the load the second time and is unsure why it happened. After locating the load, he picked helitack up at the helispot and we returned to the airport, ending the day.
Foward rotor head horizontal pin bearing inspection due.

Upon departure from 6D9 to return to CAD (home airport) after Forest detection mission, pilot observed and reported to Forest dispatch a wildfire occurring south of Sand Lake.  The fire was approximately one acre in size, burning in grass and hardwood litter.  Ausable Task Force and Pine River engine were dispatched for suppression.  Due to the inoperable radio system in using command and repeater frequencies, Huron dispatch kept the patrol plane over site of fire and relayed and received through Huron detection frequency via the pilot all communication with ground resources.  Dispatcher also communicated via cell phone with L.E.O. 3520 with very poor cell reception.  Suppression mission was accomplished, but the safety/comfort communication zone was absent, causing concern and apprehension.On Monday, April 28th, the Huron National Forest's task forces (Mio and Huron Shores) responded to six fires (including one at 531 acres, one at 150 acres and one at 50 acres) with the same communication problems and again Huron dispatch had to rely on the patrol planes (2) for communication with ground forces.  There were also fires on April 25th, 27th, and 30th with the same communication problems.
